[[January 28]]

==Events==
*1077 &ndash; Walk to Canossa: The excommunication of Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor is lifted.
*1393 &ndash; King Charles VI of France is nearly killed when several dancers' costumes catch fire during a masquerade ball.
*1521 &ndash; The Diet of Worms begins, lasting until May 25.
*1547 &ndash; Henry VIII dies. His nine-year-old son, Edward VI becomes King, and the first Protestant ruler of England.
*1573 &ndash; Articles of the Warsaw Confederation are signed, sanctioning freedom of religion in Poland.
*1624 &ndash; Sir Thomas Warner founds the first British colony in the Caribbean, on the island of Saint Kitts.
*1701 &ndash; The Chinese storm Dartsedo.
*1724 &ndash; The Russian Academy of Sciences is founded in St. Petersburg by Peter the Great, and implemented by Senate decree. It is called the St. Petersburg Academy of Sciences until 1917.
*1754 &ndash; Horace Walpole coins the word serendipity in a letter to Horace Mann.
*1760 &ndash; Pownal, Vermont is created by Benning Wentworth as one of the New Hampshire Grants.
*1813 &ndash; Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice is first published in the United Kingdom.
*1820 &ndash; A Russian expedition led by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen and Mikhail Petrovich Lazarev discovers the Antarctic continent, approaching the Antarctic coast.
*1821 &ndash; Alexander Island is first discovered by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen.
*1846 &ndash; The Battle of Aliwal, India, is won by British troops commanded by Sir Harry Smith.
*1851 &ndash; Northwestern University becomes the first chartered university in Illinois.
*1855 &ndash; A locomotive on the Panama Canal Railway, runs from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific Ocean for the first time.
*1871 &ndash; Franco-Prussian War: the Siege of Paris ends in French defeat and an armistice.
*1878 &ndash; Yale Daily News becomes the first daily college newspaper in the United States.
*1887 &ndash; In a snowstorm at Fort Keogh, Montana, the world's largest snowflakes are reported, 15 in wide and 8 in thick.
*1896 &ndash; Walter Arnold of East Peckham, Kent becomes the first person to be convicted of speeding. He was fined 1 shilling, plus costs, for speeding at 8 mph, thus exceeding the contemporary speed limit of 2 mph.
*1902 &ndash; The Carnegie Institution of Washington is founded in Washington, D.C. with a $10 million gift from Andrew Carnegie.
*1908 &ndash; Members of the Portuguese Republican Party fail in their attempted coup d'tat against the administrative dictatorship of Prime Minister Joo Franco.
*1909 &ndash; United States troops leave Cuba with the exception of Guantanamo Bay Naval Base after being there since the SpanishAmerican War.
*1915 &ndash; An act of the U.S. Congress creates the United States Coast Guard as a branch of the United States Armed Forces.
*1917 &ndash; Municipally-owned streetcars take to the streets of San Francisco.
*1918 &ndash; Finnish Civil War: Rebels seize control of the capital, Helsinki, and members of the Senate of Finland go underground.
*1922 &ndash; Knickerbocker Storm, Washington D.C.'s biggest snowfall, causes the city's greatest loss of life when the roof of the Knickerbocker Theatre collapses.
*1932 &ndash; Japanese forces attack Shanghai.
*1933 &ndash; The name Pakistan is coined by Choudhry Rahmat Ali Khan and is accepted by the Indian Muslims who then thereby adopted it further for the Pakistan Movement seeking independence.
*1934 &ndash; The first ski tow in the United States begins operation in Vermont.
*1935 &ndash; Iceland becomes the first Western country to legalize therapeutic abortion.
*1938 &ndash; The World Land Speed Record on a public road is broken by Rudolf Caracciola in the Mercedes-Benz W195 at a speed of 432.7 km/h.
*1941 &ndash; Franco-Thai War: Final air battle of the conflict. A Japanese-mediated armistice goes into effect later in the day.
*1945 &ndash; World War II: Supplies begin to reach the Republic of China over the newly reopened Burma Road.
*1956 &ndash; Elvis Presley makes his first US television appearance
*1958 &ndash; The Lego company patents the design of its Lego bricks, still compatible with bricks produced today.
* 1958 &ndash; The last episode of the British radio comedy programme The Goon Show is broadcast.
* 1960 &ndash; The National Football League announced expansion teams for Dallas to start in the 1960 NFL season and Minneapolis-St. Paul for 1961 NFL season.
*1964 &ndash; An unarmed USAF T-39 Sabreliner on a training mission is shot down over Erfurt, East Germany, by a Soviet MiG-19.
*1965 &ndash; The current design of the Flag of Canada is chosen by an act of Parliament.
*1977 &ndash; The first day of the Great Lakes Blizzard of 1977 which dumps 10 ft of snow in one-day in Upstate New York, with Buffalo, Syracuse, Watertown, and surrounding areas most affected. Disintegration of the Space Shuttle Challenger.
*1979 &ndash; CBS News Sunday Morning debuts with original host and cocreator Charles Kuralt.
*1979 &ndash; Pope John Paul II starts his first pastoral visit to Mexico.
*1980 &ndash; collides with the tanker Capricorn while leaving Tampa Florida and capsizes killing 23 Coast Guard crewmembers.
*1981 &ndash; Ronald Reagan lifts remaining domestic petroleum price and allocation controls in the United States helping to end the 1979 energy crisis and begin the 1980s oil glut.
*1982 &ndash; US Army general James L. Dozier is rescued by Italian anti-terrorism forces from captivity by the Red Brigades.
*1984 &ndash; Tropical Storm Domoina makes landfall in southern Mozambique, eventually causing 214 deaths and some of the most severe flooding so far recorded in the region.
*1985 &ndash; Supergroup USA for Africa (United Support of Artists for Africa) records the hit single We Are the World, to help raise funds for Ethiopian famine relief.
*1986 &ndash; Space Shuttle program: STS-51-L mission &ndash; Space Shuttle Challenger explodes after liftoff killing all seven astronauts on board.
*1988 &ndash; In R. v. Morgentaler the Supreme Court of Canada strikes down all anti-abortion laws, effectively allowing abortions in Canada in all 9 months of pregnancy.
*2002 &ndash; TAME Flight 120, a Boeing 727-100 crashes in the Andes mountains in southern Colombia killing 92.
*2006 &ndash; The roof of one of the buildings at the Katowice International Fair in Chorzw/Katowice, Poland, collapses due to the weight of snow, killing 65 and injuring more than 170 others.
*2010 &ndash; Five murderers of President Sheikh Mujibur Rahman of Bangladesh are hanged.

[[January 31]]

==Events==
* 314 &ndash; Silvester I begins his reign as Pope of the Catholic Church, succeeding Pope Miltiades.
*1504 &ndash; France cedes Naples to Aragon.
*1606 &ndash; Gunpowder Plot: Guy Fawkes is executed for plotting against Parliament and King James.
*1747 &ndash; The first venereal diseases clinic opens at London Lock Hospital.
*1801 &ndash; John Marshall is appointed the Chief Justice of the United States.
*1814 &ndash; Gervasio Antonio de Posadas becomes Supreme Director of Argentina.
*1846 &ndash; After the Milwaukee Bridge War, Juneautown and Kilbourntown unify as the City of Milwaukee, Wisconsin.
*1848 &ndash; John C. Frmont is Court-martialed for mutiny and disobeying orders.
*1849 &ndash; Corn Laws are abolished in the United Kingdom pursuant to legislation in 1846.
*1862 &ndash; Alvan Graham Clark discovers the white dwarf star Sirius B, a companion of Sirius, through an 18.5 in telescope now located at Northwestern University.
*1865 &ndash; American Civil War: The United States Congress passes the Thirteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, abolishing slavery and submits it to the states for ratification.
* 1865 &ndash; American Civil War: Confederate General Robert E. Lee becomes general-in-chief.
*1867 &ndash; Maronite nationalist leader Youssef Karam leaves Lebanon on board a French ship bound for Algeria.
*1891 &ndash; History of Portugal: The first attempt at a Portuguese republican revolution breaks out in the northern city of Porto.
*1900 &ndash; Datu Muhammad Salleh is assassinated in Kampung Teboh, Tambunan, ending the Mat Salleh Rebellion.
*1915 &ndash; World War I: Germany is the first to make large-scale use of poison gas in warfare in the Battle of Bolimw against Russia.
*1917 &ndash; World War I: Germany announces that its U-boats will resume unrestricted submarine warfare after a two-year hiatus.
*1918 &ndash; A series of accidental collisions on a misty Scottish night leads to the loss of two Royal Navy submarines with over a hundred lives, and damage to another five British warships.
*1919 &ndash; The Battle of George Square takes place in Glasgow, Scotland.
*1929 &ndash; The Soviet Union exiles Leon Trotsky.
*1930 &ndash; 3M begins marketing Scotch Tape.
*1942 &ndash; World War II: Allied forces are defeated by the Japanese at the Battle of Malaya and retreat to the island of Singapore.
*1943 &ndash; World War II: German Field Marshal Friedrich Paulus surrenders to the Soviets at Stalingrad, followed 2 days later by the remainder of his Sixth Army, ending one of the war's fiercest battles.
*1944 &ndash; World War II: American forces land on Kwajalein Atoll and other islands in the Japanese-held Marshall Islands.
* 1944 &ndash; World War II: During the Anzio campaign the 1st Ranger Battalion (Darby's Rangers) is destroyed behind enemy lines in a heavily outnumbered encounter at Battle of Cisterna, Italy.
*1945 &ndash; US Army private Eddie Slovik is executed for desertion, the first such execution of an American soldier since the Civil War.
* 1945 &ndash; World War II: About 3,000 inmates from the Stutthof concentration camp are forcibly marched into the Baltic Sea at Palmnicken (now Yantarny, Russia) and executed.
*1946 &ndash; Yugoslavia's new constitution, modeling that of the Soviet Union, establishes six constituent republics (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia and Slovenia).
*1949 &ndash; These Are My Children, the first television daytime soap opera is broadcast by the NBC station in Chicago.
*1950 &ndash; President Harry S. Truman announces a program to develop the hydrogen bomb.
*1953 &ndash; A North Sea flood causes over 1,800 deaths in the Netherlands and over 300 in the United Kingdom
*1957 &ndash; Eight people on the ground in Pacoima, California are killed following the mid-air collision between a Douglas DC-7 airliner and a Northrop F-89 Scorpion fighter jet.
*1958 &ndash; Explorer program: Explorer 1 &ndash; The first successful launch of an American satellite into orbit.
* 1958 &ndash; James Van Allen discovers the Van Allen radiation belt.
*1961 &ndash; Project Mercury: Mercury-Redstone 2 &ndash; Ham the Chimp travels into outer space.
*1966 &ndash; The Soviet Union launches the unmanned Luna 9 spacecraft as part of the Luna program.
*1968 &ndash; Viet Cong attack the United States embassy in Saigon, and other attacks, in the early morning hours, later grouped together as the Tet Offensive.
* 1968 &ndash; Nauru gains independence from Australia.
*1971 &ndash; Apollo program: Apollo 14 &ndash; Astronauts Alan Shepard, Stuart Roosa, and Edgar Mitchell, aboard a Saturn V, lift off for a mission to the Fra Mauro Highlands on the Moon.
* 1971 &ndash; The Winter Soldier Investigation, organized by the Vietnam Veterans Against the War to publicize war crimes and atrocities by Americans and allies in Vietnam, begins in Detroit, Michigan.
*1990 &ndash; The first McDonald's in the Soviet Union opens in Moscow.
*1995 &ndash; President Bill Clinton authorizes a $20 billion loan to Mexico to stabilize its economy.
*1996 &ndash; An explosives-filled truck rams into the gates of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka in Colombo, Sri Lanka killing at least 86 and injuring 1,400.
* 1996 &ndash; Comet Hyakutake is discovered by Japanese amateur astronomer Yuji Hyakutake.
*2000 &ndash; Alaska Airlines Flight 261 crash: An MD-83, experiencing horizontal stabilizer problems, crashes in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Point Mugu, California, killing all 88 aboard.
*2001 &ndash; In the Netherlands, a Scottish court convicts Libyan Abdelbaset al-Megrahi and acquits another Libyan citizen for their part in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland in 1988.
*2003 &ndash; The Waterfall rail accident occurs near Waterfall, New South Wales, Australia.
*2007 &ndash; Suspects are arrested in Birmingham in the UK, accused of plotting the kidnap, holding and eventual beheading of a serving Muslim British soldier in Iraq.
*2009 &ndash; In Kenya, at least 113 people are killed and over 200 injured following an oil spillage ignition in Molo, days after a massive fire at a Nakumatt supermarket in Nairobi killed at least 25 people.
*2010 &ndash; Avatar becomes the first film to gross over $2 billion worldwide.
*2011 &ndash; A winter storm hits North America for the second time in the same month, causing $1.8 billion in damage across the United States and Canada and killing 24 people.
*2013 &ndash; An explosion at the Pemex Executive Tower in Mexico City kills at least 33 people and injures more than 100.

[[June 6]]

==Events==
*1508 &ndash; Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor, is defeated in Friuli by Venetian troops
*1513 &ndash; Italian Wars: Battle of Novara. Swiss troops defeat the French under Louis de la Tremoille, forcing the French to abandon Milan. Duke Massimiliano Sforza is restored.
*1523 &ndash; Gustav Vasa, the Swedish regent, is elected King of Sweden, marking a symbolic end to the Kalmar Union. This is the Swedish national day.
*1586 &ndash; Francis Drake's forces raid St. Augustine in Spanish Florida.
*1644 &ndash; The Qing dynasty Manchu forces led by the Shunzhi Emperor capture Beijing during the collapse of the Ming dynasty. 
*1654 &ndash; Queen Christina abdicates the Swedish throne and is succeeded by her cousin Charles X Gustav.
*1674 &ndash; Shivaji, founder of the Maratha Empire, is crowned.
*1683 &ndash; The Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, England, opens as the world's first university museum.
*1752 &ndash; A devastating fire destroys one-third of Moscow, including 18,000 homes.
*1762 &ndash; British forces begin a siege of Havana and temporarily capture the city in the Battle of Havana. 
*1808 &ndash; Napoleon's brother, Joseph Bonaparte, is crowned King of Spain.
*1809 &ndash; Sweden promulgates a new Constitution, which restores political power to the Riksdag of the Estates after 20 years of enlightened absolutism. At the same time, Charles XIII is elected to succeed Gustav IV Adolf as King of Sweden.
*1813 &ndash; War of 1812: Battle of Stoney Creek &ndash; A British force of 700 under John Vincent defeats an American force twice its size under William Winder and John Chandler.
*1822 &ndash; Alexis St. Martin is accidentally shot in the stomach, leading to William Beaumont's studies on digestion.
*1832 &ndash; The June Rebellion in Paris is put down by the National Guard.
*1833 &ndash; Andrew Jackson becomes the first U.S. President to ride on a train.
*1844 &ndash; The Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA) is founded in London.
*1857 &ndash; Sophia of Nassau marries the future King Oscar II of SwedenNorway.
*1859 &ndash; Australia: Queensland is established as a separate colony from New South Wales (Queensland Day).
*1862 &ndash; American Civil War: Battle of Memphis &ndash; Union forces capture Memphis, Tennessee, from the Confederates.
*1882 &ndash; More than 100,000 inhabitants of Bombay are killed when a cyclone in the Arabian Sea pushes huge waves into the harbour.
* 1882 &ndash; The Shewan forces of Menelik II of Ethiopia defeat the Gojjame army in the Battle of Embabo. The Shewans capture Negus Tekle Haymanot of Gojjam, and their victory leads to a Shewan hegemony over the territories south of the Abay River.
*1889 &ndash; The Great Seattle Fire destroys all of downtown Seattle.
*1892 &ndash; The Chicago 'L' commuter rail system begins operation
*1894 &ndash; Governor Davis H. Waite orders the Colorado state militia to protect and support the miners engaged in the Cripple Creek miners' strike.
*1909 &ndash; French troops capture Abch (in modern-day Chad) and install a puppet sultan in the Ouaddai Empire.
*1912 &ndash; The eruption of Novarupta in Alaska begins. It is the second largest volcanic eruption of the 20th century.
*1918 &ndash; World War I: Battle of Belleau Wood &ndash; The U.S. Marine Corps suffers its worst single day's casualties while attempting to recapture the wood at Chteau-Thierry.
*1919 &ndash; The Republic of Prekmurje ends.
*1921 &ndash; Southwark Bridge in London is opened to traffic by King George V and Queen Mary.
*1932 &ndash; The Revenue Act of 1932 is enacted, creating the first gas tax in the United States, at a rate of 1 cent per US gallon (/L) sold.
*1933 &ndash; The first drive-in theater opens, in Camden, New Jersey, United States.
*1934 &ndash; New Deal: the U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs the Securities Act of 1933 into law, establishing the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.
*1939 &ndash; Judge Joseph Force Crater, known as the "Missingest Man in New York", is declared legally dead.
*1942 &ndash; World War II: Battle of Midway. U.S. Navy dive bombers sink the Japanese cruiser Mikuma and four Japanese carriers.
*1944 &ndash; World War II: the Battle of Normandy begins. D-Day, code named Operation Overlord, commences with the landing of 155,000 Allied troops on the beaches of Normandy in France. The allied soldiers quickly break through the Atlantic Wall and push inland in the largest amphibious military operation in history.
*1946 &ndash; The National Basketball Association is created with eleven teams.
*1964 &ndash; Under a temporary order, the rocket launches at Cuxhaven, Germany are terminated. They never resume.
*1968 &ndash; Assassination of Robert F. Kennedy: Robert F. Kennedy, Democratic Party senator from New York and brother of 35th President John F. Kennedy, dies from gunshot wounds inflicted on June 5.
*1971 &ndash; Soyuz program: Soyuz 11 is launched.
* 1971 &ndash; A midair collision between a Hughes Airwest Douglas DC-9 jetliner and a United States Marine Corps McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II jet fighter near Duarte, California, claims 50 lives.
* 1971 &ndash; Vietnam War: the Battle of Long Khanh between Australian and Vietnamese communist forces begins.
*1974 &ndash; A new Instrument of Government is promulgated making Sweden a parliamentary monarchy.
*1981 &ndash; Bihar train disaster: a passenger train travelling between Mansi and Saharsa, India, jumps the tracks at a bridge crossing the Bagmati river. The government places the official death toll at 268 plus another 300 missing; however, it is generally believed that the death toll is closer to 1,000.
*1982 &ndash; The 1982 Lebanon War begins. Forces under Israeli Defense Minister Ariel Sharon invade southern Lebanon during Operation Peace for the Galilee, eventually reaching as far north as the capital Beirut.
*1982 &ndash; A British Army Air Corps Gazelle helicopter is destroyed in a friendly fire incident, resulting in the loss of four lives.
*1984 &ndash; Tetris, one of the best-selling video games of all time, is released.
*1985 &ndash; The grave of "Wolfgang Gerhard" is opened in Embu, Brazil; the exhumed remains are later proven to be those of Josef Mengele, Auschwitz's "Angel of Death". Mengele is thought to have drowned while swimming in February 1979.
*1992 &ndash; The Fantoft Stave Church in Norway is destroyed by Varg Vikernes. This was the first in a string of church arsons in the Early Norwegian black metal scene
*1993 &ndash; Mongolia holds its first direct presidential elections.
*1997 &ndash; Prom Mom incident: While attending her senior prom in Lacey Township, New Jersey, Melissa Drexler gives birth in a bathroom stall, leaves the baby to die in a trash can and then returns to the prom.
*2002 &ndash; Eastern Mediterranean event. A near-Earth asteroid estimated at ten meters in diameter explodes over the Mediterranean Sea between Greece and Libya. The resulting explosion is estimated to have a force of 26 kilotons, slightly more powerful than the Nagasaki atomic bomb.
*2004 &ndash; Tamil is established as a "classical language" by the President of India, Dr. A. P. J. Abdul Kalam, in a joint sitting of the two houses of the Indian Parliament.
*2005 &ndash; In Gonzales v. Raich, the United States Supreme Court upholds a federal law banning cannabis, including medical marijuana.

[[June 7]]

==Events==
* 421 &ndash; Emperor Theodosius II marries Aelia Eudocia. The wedding was celebrated at Constantinople (Byzantine Empire).
*1099 &ndash; First Crusade: The Siege of Jerusalem begins.
*1420 &ndash; Troops of the Republic of Venice capture Udine, ending the independence of the Patriarchal State of Friuli.
*1494 &ndash; Spain and Portugal sign the Treaty of Tordesillas which divides the New World between the two countries.
*1628 &ndash; The Petition of Right, a major English constitutional document, is granted the Royal Assent by Charles I and becomes law.
*1654 &ndash; Louis XIV is crowned King of France.
*1692 &ndash; Port Royal, Jamaica, was hit by a catastrophic earthquake; in just three minutes, 1,600 people were killed and 3,000 were seriously injured.
*1776 &ndash; Richard Henry Lee presents the "Lee Resolution" to the Continental Congress. The motion was seconded by John Adams and led to the United States Declaration of Independence.
*1788 &ndash; French Revolution: Day of the Tiles  civilians in Grenoble toss roof tiles and various objects down upon royal troops.
*1800 &ndash; David Thompson reaches the mouth of the Saskatchewan River in Manitoba.
*1810 &ndash; The newspaper Gazeta de Buenos Ayres is first published in Argentina.
*1832 &ndash; Asian cholera reaches Quebec, brought by Irish immigrants, and kills about 6,000 people in Lower Canada.
*1862 &ndash; The United States and the United Kingdom agree to suppress the slave trade.
*1863 &ndash; During the French intervention in Mexico, Mexico City is captured by French troops.
*1866 &ndash; 1,800 Fenian raiders are repelled back to the United States after they looted and plundered around Saint-Armand and Frelighsburg, Quebec.
*1880 &ndash; War of the Pacific: The Battle of Arica, the assault and capture of Morro de Arica (Arica Cape), ends the Campaa del Desierto (Desert Campaign).
*1892 &ndash; Benjamin Harrison becomes the first President of the United States to attend a baseball game.
* 1892 &ndash; Homer Plessy is arrested for refusing to leave his seat in the "whites-only" car of a train; he lost the resulting court case, Plessy v. Ferguson.
*1893 &ndash; Mohandas Gandhi commits his first act of civil disobedience.
*1899 &ndash; American Temperance crusader Carrie Nation begins her campaign of vandalizing alcohol-serving establishments by destroying the inventory in a saloon in Kiowa, Kansas.
*1905 &ndash; Norway's parliament dissolves its union with Sweden. The vote was confirmed by a national plebiscite on August 13 of that year.
*1906 &ndash; Cunard Line's is launched from the John Brown Shipyard, Glasgow (Clydebank), Scotland.
*1909 &ndash; Mary Pickford makes her screen debut at the age of 16.
*1917 &ndash; World War I: Battle of Messines &ndash; Allied soldiers detonate ammonal mines underneath German trenches at Messines Ridge, killing 10,000 German troops.
*1919 &ndash; Sette giugno: Four people are killed in a riot in Malta.
*1929 &ndash; The Lateran Treaty is ratified, bringing Vatican City into existence.
*1936 &ndash; The Steel Workers Organizing Committee, a trade union, is founded in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Philip Murray was elected its first president.
*1938 &ndash; The Douglas DC-4E makes its first test flight.
* 1938 &ndash; Second Sino-Japanese War: The Chinese Nationalist government creates the 1938 Yellow River flood to halt Japanese forces. 500,000 to 900,000 civilians are killed.
*1940 &ndash; King Haakon VII, Crown Prince Olav and the Norwegian government leaves Troms and goes into exile in London. They return exactly five years later
*1942 &ndash; World War II: The Battle of Midway ends in American victory.
* 1942 &ndash; World War II: Aleutian Islands Campaign: Imperial Japanese soldiers begin occupying the American islands of Attu and Kiska, in the Aleutian Islands off Alaska.
*1944 &ndash; World War II: The steamer Danae, carrying 350 Cretan Jews and 250 Cretan partisans, is sunk without survivors off the shore of Santorini.
* 1944 &ndash; World War II: Battle of Normandy &ndash; At Abbey Ardennes, members of the SS Division Hitlerjugend massacre 23 Canadian prisoners of war.
*1948 &ndash; Edvard Bene resigns as President of Czechoslovakia rather than signing the Ninth-of-May Constitution, making his nation a Communist state.
*1955 &ndash; Lux Radio Theater signs off the air permanently. The show launched in New York in 1934, and featured radio adaptations of Broadway shows and popular films.
*1965 &ndash; The Supreme Court of the United States hands down its decision in Griswold v. Connecticut, effectively legalizing the use of contraception by married couples.
*1967 &ndash; Six-Day War: Israeli soldiers enter Jerusalem.
*1971 &ndash; The United States Supreme Court overturned the conviction of Paul Cohen for disturbing the peace, setting the precedent that vulgar writing is protected under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution.
* 1971 &ndash; The Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms Division of the U.S. Internal Revenue Service raids the home of Ken Ballew for illegal possession of hand grenades.
*1975 &ndash; The inaugural Cricket World Cup began in England.
*1977 &ndash; 500 million people watched the high day of the Silver Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II begin on television.
*1981 &ndash; The Israeli Air Force destroyed Iraq's Osiraq nuclear reactor during Operation Opera.
*1982 &ndash; Priscilla Presley opens Graceland to the public; the bathroom where Elvis Presley died five years earlier was kept off-limits.
*1990 &ndash; Universal Studios Florida opens in Orlando, FL.
*1991 &ndash; Mount Pinatubo erupts, generating an ash column 7 km high.
*1995 &ndash; The long-range Boeing 777 enters service with United Airlines.
*2000 &ndash; The United Nations defines the Blue Line as the border between Israel and Lebanon.

[[June 11]]

==Events==
*1184 BC &ndash; Trojan War: Troy is sacked and burned, according to calculations by Eratosthenes.
*323 BC &ndash; Alexander the Great dies in the palace of Nebuchadnezzar II in Babylon
* 173 &ndash; Marcomannic Wars: The Roman army in Moravia is encircled by the Quadi, who have broken the peace treaty (171). In a violent thunderstorm emperor Marcus Aurelius defeats and subdues them in the so-called "miracle of the rain".
* 631 &ndash; Emperor Taizong of Tang, the Emperor of China, sends envoys to the Xueyantuo bearing gold and silk in order to seek the release of enslaved Chinese prisoners captured during the transition from Sui to Tang from the northern frontier; this embassy succeeded in freeing 80,000 Chinese men and women who were then returned to China.
* 786 &ndash; A Hasanid Alid uprising in Mecca is crushed by the Abbasids at the Battle of Fakhkh. Idris ibn Abdallah flees to the Maghreb, where he later founds the Idrisid dynasty.
*1345 &ndash; The megas doux Alexios Apokaukos, chief minister of the Byzantine Empire, is lynched by political prisoners.
*1429 &ndash; Hundred Years' War: start of the Battle of Jargeau.
*1488 &ndash; Battle of Sauchieburn: fought between rebel Lords and James III of Scotland, resulting in the death of the King.
*1509 &ndash; Henry VIII of England marries Catherine of Aragon.
*1594 &ndash; Philip II recognizes the rights and privileges of the local nobles and chieftains in the Philippines, which paved way to the stabilization of the rule of the Principala (an elite ruling class of native nobility in Spanish Philippines).
*1770 &ndash; British explorer Captain James Cook runs aground on the Great Barrier Reef.
*1775 &ndash; The American Revolutionary War's first naval engagement, the Battle of Machias, results in the capture of a small British naval vessel.
*1776 &ndash; The Continental Congress appoints Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, Benjamin Franklin, Roger Sherman, and Robert R. Livingston to the Committee of Five to draft a declaration of independence.
*1788 &ndash; Russian explorer Gerasim Izmailov reaches Alaska.
*1805 &ndash; A fire consumes large portions of Detroit in the Michigan Territory.
*1825 &ndash; The first cornerstone is laid for Fort Hamilton in New York City.
*1837 &ndash; The Broad Street Riot occurs in Boston, fueled by ethnic tensions between Yankees and Irish.
*1865 &ndash; The Naval Battle of Riachuelo is fought on the rivulet Riachuelo (Argentina), between the Paraguayan Navy on one side and the Brazilian Navy on the other. The Brazilian victory was crucial for the later success of the Triple Alliance (Brazil, Uruguay and Argentina) in the Paraguayan War. 
*1892 &ndash; The Limelight Department, one of the world's first film studios, is officially established in Melbourne, Australia.
*1898 &ndash; Spanish-American War: U.S. war ships set sail for Cuba.
* 1898 &ndash; The Hundred Days' Reform is started by Guangxu Emperor with a plan to change social, political and educational institutions in China, but is suspended by Empress Dowager Cixi after 104 days. The failed reform though led to the abolition of Imperial Examination in 1905.
*1901 &ndash; New Zealand annexes the Cook Islands.
*1903 &ndash; A group of Serbian officers stormed royal palace and assassinated King Alexander Obrenovi and his wife queen Draga.
*1907 &ndash; George Dennett, aided by Gilbert Jessop, dismisses Northamptonshire for 12 runs, the lowest total in first-class cricket.
*1917 &ndash; King Alexander assumes the throne of Greece after his father Constantine I abdicates under pressure by allied armies occupying Athens.
*1919 &ndash; Sir Barton wins the Belmont Stakes, becoming the first horse to win the Triple Crown.
*1920 &ndash; During the U.S. Republican National Convention in Chicago, U.S. Republican Party leaders gathered in a room at the Blackstone Hotel to come to a consensus on their candidate for the U.S. presidential election, leading the Associated Press to first coin the political phrase "smoke-filled room".
*1935 &ndash; Inventor Edwin Armstrong gives the first public demonstration of FM broadcasting in the United States at Alpine, New Jersey.
*1936 &ndash; The International Surrealist Exhibition opens in London, England.
*1937 &ndash; Great Purge: The Soviet Union under Joseph Stalin executes eight army leaders.
*1938 &ndash; Second Sino-Japanese War: The Battle of Wuhan starts.
*1942 &ndash; World War II: The United States agrees to send Lend-Lease aid to the Soviet Union.
*1944 &ndash; , the last battleship built by the United States Navy and future site of the signing of the Japanese Instrument of Surrender, is commissioned.
*1955 &ndash; Eighty-three spectators are killed and at least 100 are injured after an Austin-Healey and a Mercedes-Benz collide at the 24 Hours of Le Mans, the deadliest ever accident in motorsports.
*1956 &ndash; Start of Gal Oya riots, the first reported ethnic riots that target minority Sri Lankan Tamils in the Eastern Province. The total number of deaths is reportedly 150.
*1962 &ndash; Frank Morris, John Anglin and Clarence Anglin allegedly become the only prisoners to escape from the prison on Alcatraz Island.
*1963 &ndash; American Civil Rights Movement: Alabama Governor George Wallace stands at the door of Foster Auditorium at the University of Alabama in an attempt to block two black students, Vivian Malone and James Hood, from attending that school. Later in the day, accompanied by federalized National Guard troops, they are able to register.
* 1963 &ndash; Buddhist monk Thich Quang Duc burns himself with gasoline in a busy Saigon intersection to protest the lack of religious freedom in South Vietnam.
* 1963 &ndash; John F. Kennedy addresses Americans from the Oval Office proposing the Civil Rights Act of 1964 that would revolutionize American society. Proposing equal access to public facilities, end segregation in education and guarantee federal protection for voting rights.
*1964 &ndash; World War II veteran Walter Seifert runs amok in an elementary school in Cologne, Germany, killing at least eight children and two teachers and seriously injuring several more with a home-made flamethrower and a lance.
*1970 &ndash; After being appointed on May 15, Anna Mae Hays and Elizabeth P. Hoisington officially receive their ranks as U.S. Army Generals, becoming the first females to do so.
*1971 &ndash; The U.S. Government forcibly removes the last holdouts to the Native American Occupation of Alcatraz, ending 19 months of control.
*1978 &ndash; Altaf Hussain founds the students' political movement All Pakistan Muhajir Students Organisation (APMSO) in Karachi University.
*1981 &ndash; A Richter Scale 6.9 magnitude earthquake at Golbaf, Iran, kills at least 2,000.
*1982 &ndash; The Sentosa Musical Fountain was officially opened as part of the second phase of construction on the island of Sentosa, Singapore.
*1987 &ndash; Diane Abbott, Paul Boateng and Bernie Grant are elected as the first black Parliamentarians in Great Britain.
*1998 &ndash; Compaq Computer pays $9 billion for Digital Equipment Corporation in the largest high-tech acquisition.
*2001 &ndash; Timothy McVeigh is executed for his role in the Oklahoma City bombing.
*2002 &ndash; Antonio Meucci is acknowledged as the first inventor of the telephone by the United States Congress.
*2004 &ndash; Cassini-Huygens makes its closest flyby of the Saturn moon Phoebe.
*2008 &ndash; Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper makes a historic official apology to Canada's First Nations in regard to a residential school abuse in which children are isolated from their homes, families and cultures for a century.

[[June 14]]

==Events==
*1158 &ndash; Munich is founded by Henry the Lion on the banks of the river Isar.
*1216 &ndash; First Barons' War: Prince Louis of France captures the city of Winchester and soon conquers over half of the Kingdom of England.
*1276 &ndash; While taking exile in Fuzhou in southern China, away from the advancing Mongol invaders, the remnants of the Song Dynasty court hold the coronation ceremony for the young prince Zhao Shi, making him Emperor Duanzong of Song.
*1285 &ndash; Second Mongol invasion of Vietnam: Forces led by Prince Trn Quang Khi of the Trn Dynasty destroy most of the invading Mongol naval fleet in a battle at Chuong Duong.
*1287 &ndash; Kublai Khan defeats the force of Nayan and other traditionalist Borjigin princes in East Mongolia and Manchuria.
*1381 &ndash; Richard II of England meets leaders of Peasants' Revolt on Blackheath. The Tower of London is stormed by rebels who enter without resistance.
*1645 &ndash; English Civil War: Battle of Naseby &ndash; 12,000 Royalist forces are beaten by 15,000 Parliamentarian soldiers.
*1667 &ndash; The Raid on the Medway by the Dutch fleet in the Second Anglo-Dutch War ends. It had lasted for five days and resulted in the worst ever defeat of the Royal Navy. 
*1775 &ndash; American Revolutionary War: the Continental Army is established by the Continental Congress, marking the birth of the United States Army.
*1777 &ndash; The Stars and Stripes is adopted by Congress as the Flag of the United States.
*1789 &ndash; Mutiny on the Bounty: mutiny survivors including Captain William Bligh and 18 others reach Timor after a nearly 7,400 km journey in an open boat.
*1789 &ndash; Whiskey distilled from maize is first produced by American clergyman the Rev Elijah Craig. It is named Bourbon because Rev Craig lived in Bourbon County, Kentucky.
*1800 &ndash; The French Army of First Consul Napoleon Bonaparte defeats the Austrians at the Battle of Marengo in Northern Italy and re-conquers Italy.
*1807 &ndash; Emperor Napoleon's French Grande Arme defeats the Russian Army at the Battle of Friedland in Poland (modern Russian Kaliningrad Oblast) ending the War of the Fourth Coalition.
*1821 &ndash; Badi VII, king of Sennar, surrenders his throne and realm to Isma'il Pasha, general of the Ottoman Empire, ending the existence of that Sudanese kingdom.
*1822 &ndash; Charles Babbage proposes a difference engine in a paper to the Royal Astronomical Society entitled "Note on the application of machinery to the computation of astronomical and mathematical tables".
*1830 &ndash; Beginning of the French colonization of Algeria: 34,000 French soldiers begin their invasion of Algiers, landing 27 kilometers west at Sidi Fredj.
*1839 &ndash; Henley Royal Regatta: the village of Henley-on-Thames, on the River Thames in Oxfordshire, stages its first regatta.
*1846 &ndash; Bear Flag Revolt begins &ndash; Anglo settlers in Sonoma, California, start a rebellion against Mexico and proclaim the California Republic.
*1863 &ndash; American Civil War: Second Battle of Winchester &ndash; a Union garrison is defeated by the Army of Northern Virginia in the Shenandoah Valley town of Winchester, Virginia.
*1863 &ndash; Second Assault on the Confederate works at the Siege of Port Hudson during the American Civil War.
*1872 &ndash; Trade unions are legalised in Canada.
*1900 &ndash; Hawaii becomes a United States territory.
*1900 &ndash; The Reichstag approves a second law that allows the expansion of the German navy.
*1907 &ndash; Norway grants women the right to vote.
*1919 &ndash; John Alcock and Arthur Whitten Brown depart from St. John's, Newfoundland on the first nonstop transatlantic flight.
*1926 &ndash; Brazil leaves the League of Nations
*1937 &ndash; Pennsylvania becomes the first (and only) state of the United States to celebrate Flag Day officially as a state holiday.

* 1937 &ndash; U.S. House of Representatives passes the Marihuana Tax Act.
*1940 &ndash; World War II: Paris falls under German occupation, and Allied forces retreat.
* 1940 &ndash; The Soviet Union presents an ultimatum to Lithuania resulting in Lithuanian loss of independence.
* 1940 &ndash; A group of 728 Polish political prisoners from Tarnw become the first residents of the Auschwitz concentration camp.
*1941 &ndash; June deportation: the first major wave of Soviet mass deportations and murder of Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians, begins.
*1944 &ndash; World War II: After several failed attempts, the British Army abandons Operation Perch, its plan to capture the German-occupied town of Caen.
*1945 &ndash; World War II: Filipino troops of the 15th, 66th and 121st Infantry Regiment, Philippine Commonwealth Army, USAFIP-NL liberate the captured in Ilocos Sur and start the Battle of Bessang Pass in Northern Luzon.
*1949 &ndash; Albert II, a rhesus monkey, rides a V2 rocket to an altitude of 134 km (83 mi), thereby becoming the first monkey in space.
*1951 &ndash; UNIVAC I is dedicated by the U.S. Census Bureau.
*1952 &ndash; The keel is laid for the nuclear submarine .
*1954 &ndash; U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs a bill into law that places the words "under God" into the United States Pledge of Allegiance.
*1955 &ndash; Chile becomes a signatory to the Buenos Aires copyright treaty.
*1959 &ndash; Disneyland Monorail System, the first daily operating monorail system in the Western Hemisphere, opens to the public in Anaheim, California.
*1959 &ndash; A group of Dominican exiles depart from Cuba and land in the Dominican Republic with the intent of overthrowing the totalitarian government of Rafael Trujillo. All but four are killed or executed.
*1962 &ndash; The European Space Research Organisation is established in Paris  later becoming the European Space Agency.
*1966 &ndash; The Vatican announces the abolition of the Index Librorum Prohibitorum ("index of prohibited books"), which was originally instituted in 1557.
*1967 &ndash; Mariner program: Mariner 5 is launched towards Venus.
*1967 &ndash; The People's Republic of China tests its first hydrogen bomb.
*1982 &ndash; Falklands War: Argentine forces in the capital Stanley conditionally surrender to British forces.
*1985 &ndash; TWA Flight 847 is hijacked by Lebanese Islamist organization Hezbollah shortly after take-off from Athens, Greece.
*1994 &ndash; The 1994 Stanley Cup riot occurs after the New York Rangers win the Stanley Cup from Vancouver, causing an estimated 1.1 million, leading to 200 arrests and injuries. 
*2002 &ndash; Near-Earth asteroid 2002 MN misses the Earth by 75000 mi, about one-third of the distance between the Earth and the Moon.

[[June 17]]

==Events==
*1462 &ndash; Vlad III the Impaler attempts to assassinate Mehmed II (The Night Attack) forcing him to retreat from Wallachia.
*1497 &ndash; Battle of Deptford Bridge &ndash; forces under King Henry VII defeat troops led by Michael An Gof.
*1565 &ndash; Matsunaga Hisahide assassinates the 13th Ashikaga shogun, Ashikaga Yoshiteru.
*1579 &ndash; Sir Francis Drake claims a land he calls Nova Albion (modern California) for England.
*1596 &ndash; The Dutch explorer Willem Barentsz discovers the Arctic archipelago of Spitsbergen. 
*1631 &ndash; Mumtaz Mahal dies during childbirth. Her husband, Mughal emperor Shah Jahan I, will spend the next 17 years building her mausoleum, the Taj Mahal.
*1673 &ndash; French explorers Jacques Marquette and Louis Jolliet reach the Mississippi River and become the first Europeans to make a detailed account of its course.
*1773 &ndash; Ccuta, Colombia, is discovered by Juana Rangel de Cullar.
*1775 &ndash; American Revolutionary War: Colonists inflict heavy casualties on British forces while losing the Battle of Bunker Hill.
*1789 &ndash; In France, the Third Estate declares itself the National Assembly.
*1839 &ndash; In the Kingdom of Hawaii, Kamehameha III issues the edict of toleration which gives Roman Catholics the freedom to worship in the Hawaiian Islands. The Hawaii Catholic Church and the Cathedral of Our Lady of Peace are established as a result.
*1843 &ndash; The Wairau Affray, the first serious clash of arms between Mori and British settlers in the New Zealand Wars, takes place.
*1861 &ndash; Battle of Vienna, Virginia in the American Civil War.
*1863 &ndash; Battle of Aldie in the Gettysburg Campaign of the American Civil War.
*1876 &ndash; American Indian Wars: Battle of the Rosebud &ndash; 1,500 Sioux and Cheyenne led by Crazy Horse beat back General George Crook's forces at Rosebud Creek in Montana Territory.
*1877 &ndash; American Indian Wars: Battle of White Bird Canyon &ndash; the Nez Perce defeat the U.S. Cavalry at White Bird Canyon in the Idaho Territory.
*1885 &ndash; The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York Harbor.
*1898 &ndash; The United States Navy Hospital Corps is established.
*1900 &ndash; Boxer Rebellion: Allied Western and Japanese forces capture the Taku Forts in Tianjin, China.
*1901 &ndash; The College Board introduces its first standardized test, the forerunner to the SAT.
*1910 &ndash; Aurel Vlaicu pilots an A. Vlaicu nr. 1 on its first flight.
*1930 &ndash; U.S. President Herbert Hoover signs the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act into law.
*1932 &ndash; Bonus Army: around a thousand World War I veterans amass at the United States Capitol as the U.S. Senate considers a bill that would give them certain benefits.
*1933 &ndash; Union Station Massacre: in Kansas City, Missouri, four FBI agents and captured fugitive Frank Nash are gunned down by gangsters attempting to free Nash.
*1939 &ndash; Last public guillotining in France: Eugen Weidmann, a convicted murderer, is guillotined in Versailles outside the Saint-Pierre prison
*1940 &ndash; World War II: sinking of the by the Luftwaffe near Saint-Nazaire, France. At least 3,000 are killed; Britain's worst maritime disaster.
* 1940 &ndash; World War II: the British Army's 11th Hussars assault and take Fort Capuzzo in Libya, Africa from Italian forces.
* 1940 &ndash; The three Baltic states of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania fall under the occupation of the Soviet Union.
*1944 &ndash; Iceland declares independence from Denmark and becomes a republic.
*1948 &ndash; A Douglas DC-6 carrying United Airlines Flight 624 crashes near Mount Carmel, Pennsylvania, killing all 43 people on board.
*1953 &ndash; East Germany Workers Uprising: in East Germany, the Soviet Union orders a division of troops into East Berlin to quell a rebellion.
*1958 &ndash; The Ironworkers Memorial Second Narrows Crossing, in the process of being built to connect Vancouver and North Vancouver (Canada), collapses into the Burrard Inlet killing many of the ironworkers and injuring others.
* 1958 &ndash; The wooden roller coaster at Playland, which is in the Pacific National Exhibition, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada opens. It is still open today.
*1960 &ndash; The Nez Perce tribe is awarded $4 million for 7 e6acre of land undervalued at 4 cents/acre in the 1863 treaty.
*1963 &ndash; The United States Supreme Court rules 8 to 1 in Abington School District v. Schempp against requiring the reciting of Bible verses and the Lord's Prayer in public schools.
* 1963 &ndash; A day after South Vietnamese President Ngo Dinh Diem announced the Joint Communique to end the Buddhist crisis, a riot involving around 2,000 people breaks out. One person is killed.
*1967 &ndash; The People's Republic of China announces a successful test of its first thermonuclear weapon.
*1971 &ndash; President Richard Nixon declares the U.S. War on Drugs.
*1972 &ndash; Watergate scandal: five White House operatives are arrested for burgling the offices of the Democratic National Committee, in an attempt by some members of the Republican party to illegally wiretap the opposition.
*1985 &ndash; STS-51-G Space Shuttle Discovery launches carrying Sultan bin Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud, the first Arab and first Muslim in space, as a Payload Specialist.
*1987 &ndash; With the death of the last individual of the species, the Dusky Seaside Sparrow becomes extinct.
*1991 &ndash; Apartheid: the South African Parliament repeals the Population Registration Act which required racial classification of all South Africans at birth.
*1992 &ndash; A "joint understanding" agreement on arms reduction is signed by U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin (this would be later codified in START II).
*1994 &ndash; Following a televised low-speed highway chase, O.J. Simpson is arrested for the murders of his wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald Goldman.

[[June 25]]

==Events==
* 524 &ndash; The Franks are defeated by the Burgundians in the Battle of Vzeronce.
* 841 &ndash; In the Battle of Fontenay-en-Puisaye, forces led by Charles the Bald and Louis the German defeat the armies of Lothair I of Italy and Pepin II of Aquitaine.
*1530 &ndash; At the Diet of Augsburg the Augsburg Confession is presented to the Holy Roman Emperor by the Lutheran princes and Electors of Germany.
*1658 &ndash; Spanish forces fail to retake Jamaica at the Battle of Rio Nuevo during the Anglo-Spanish War.
*1678 &ndash; Venetian Elena Cornaro Piscopia is the first woman awarded a doctorate of philosophy when she graduates from the University of Padua.
*1741 &ndash; Maria Theresa of Austria is crowned Queen of Hungary.
*1786 &ndash; Gavriil Pribylov discovers St. George Island of the Pribilof Islands in the Bering Sea.
*1788 &ndash; Virginia becomes the 10th state to ratify the United States Constitution.
*1876 &ndash; Battle of the Little Bighorn and the death of Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer.
*1900 &ndash; The Daoist monk Wang Yuanlu discovers the Dunhuang manuscripts, a cache of ancient texts that are of great historical and religious significance, in the Mogao Caves of Dunhuang, China.
*1906 &ndash; Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania millionaire Harry Thaw shoots and kills prominent architect Stanford White.
*1910 &ndash; The United States Congress passes the Mann Act, which prohibits interstate transport of females for immoral purposes; the ambiguous language would be used to selectively prosecute people for years to come.
* 1910 &ndash; Igor Stravinsky's ballet The Firebird is premiered in Paris, bringing him to prominence as a composer.
*1913 &ndash; American Civil War veterans begin arriving at the Great Reunion of 1913.
*1923 &ndash; Capt. Lowell H. Smith and Lt. John P. Richter perform the first ever aerial refueling in a DH-4B biplane
*1935 &ndash; Diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and Colombia are established.
*1938 &ndash; Dr. Douglas Hyde is inaugurated as the first President of Ireland.
*1940 &ndash; World War II: France officially surrenders to Germany at 01:35.
*1943 &ndash; The Holocaust: Jews in the Czstochowa Ghetto in Poland stage an uprising against the Nazis.
*1944 &ndash; World War II: The Battle of Tali-Ihantala, the largest battle ever fought in the Nordic Countries, begins.
* 1944 &ndash; World War II: United States Navy and Royal Navy ships bombard Cherbourg to support United States Army units engaged in the Battle of Cherbourg.
* 1944 &ndash; The final page of the comic Krazy Kat was published, exactly two months after its author George Herriman died.
*1947 &ndash; The Diary of a Young Girl (better known as The Diary of Anne Frank) is published.
*1948 &ndash; The Berlin airlift begins.
*1949 &ndash; Long-Haired Hare, starring Bugs Bunny, is released in theaters.
*1950 &ndash; The Korean War begins with the invasion of South Korea by North Korea.
*1960 &ndash; Two cryptographers working for the United States National Security Agency left for vacation to Mexico, and from there defected to the Soviet Union. 
*1967 &ndash; Broadcasting of the first live global satellite television program: Our World
*1975 &ndash; Mozambique achieves independence.
*1976 &ndash; Missouri Governor Kit Bond issues an executive order rescinding the Extermination Order, formally apologizing on behalf of the state of Missouri for the suffering it had caused to the members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints.
*1975 &ndash; Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has a state of internal Emergency declared in India.
*1978 &ndash; The rainbow flag representing gay pride is flown for the first time in the San Francisco Gay Freedom Day Parade.
*1981 &ndash; Microsoft is restructured to become an incorporated business in its home state of Washington.
*1982 &ndash; Greece abolishes the head shaving of recruits in the military.
*1991 &ndash; Croatia and Slovenia declare their independence from Yugoslavia.
*1993 &ndash; Kim Campbell is chosen as leader of the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada and becomes the first female Prime Minister of Canada.
*1996 &ndash; The Khobar Towers bombing in Saudi Arabia kills 19 U.S. servicemen.
*1997 &ndash; An unmanned Progress spacecraft collides with the Russian space station Mir.
* 1997 &ndash; The Soufrire Hills volcano in Montserrat erupts resulting in the death of 19 people.
*1998 &ndash; In Clinton v. City of New York, the United States Supreme Court decides that the Line Item Veto Act of 1996 is unconstitutional.
*2006 &ndash; Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier, is kidnapped by Palestinian militants in a cross-border raid from the Israeli territory.
*2013 &ndash; Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani becomes the 8th Emir of Qatar.

[[June 26]]

==Events==
* 221 &ndash; Roman Emperor Elagabalus adopts his cousin Alexander Severus as his heir and receives the title of Caesar.
* 363 &ndash; Roman Emperor Julian is killed during the retreat from the Sassanid Empire. General Jovian is proclaimed Emperor by the troops on the battlefield.
* 699 &ndash; En no Ozuno, a Japanese mystic and apothecary who will later be regarded as the founder of a folk religion Shugend, is banished to Izu shima.
*1409 &ndash; Western Schism: the Roman Catholic church is led into a double schism as Petros Philargos is crowned Pope Alexander V after the Council of Pisa, joining Pope Gregory XII in Rome and Pope Benedict XII in Avignon.
*1541 &ndash; Francisco Pizarro is assassinated in Lima by the son of his former companion and later antagonist, Diego Almagro the younger. Almagro is later caught and executed.
*1718 &ndash; Tsarevich Alexei Petrovich of Russia, Peter the Great's son, mysteriously dies after being sentenced to death by his father for plotting against him.
*1723 &ndash; After a siege and bombardment by cannon, Baku surrenders to the Russians.
*1740 &ndash; A combined force Spanish, free blacks and allied Indians defeat a British garrison at the Siege of Fort Mose near St. Augustine during the War of Jenkins' Ear.
*1848 &ndash; End of the June Days Uprising in Paris.
*1857 &ndash; The first investiture of the Victoria Cross in Hyde Park, London.
*1870 &ndash; The Christian holiday of Christmas is declared a federal holiday in the United States.
*1886 &ndash; Henri Moissan isolated elemental Fluorine for the first time.
*1906 &ndash; 1906 French Grand Prix, the first Grand Prix motor racing event held
*1907 &ndash; The 1907 Tiflis bank robbery took place in Yerevan Square, now Freedom Square, Tbilisi.
*1909 &ndash; The Science Museum in London comes into existence as an independent entity.
*1917 &ndash; The first U.S. troops arrive in France to fight alongside Britain and France against Germany in World War I.
*1918 &ndash; World War I, Western Front: Battle for Belleau Wood &ndash; Allied Forces under John J. Pershing and James Harbord defeat Imperial German Forces under Wilhelm, German Crown Prince.
*1924 &ndash; American occupying forces leave the Dominican Republic.
*1927 &ndash; The Cyclone roller coaster opens on Coney Island.
*1934 &ndash; President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs the Federal Credit Union Act, which establishes credit unions.
*1936 &ndash; Initial flight of the Focke-Wulf Fw 61, the first practical helicopter.
*1940 &ndash; World War II: under the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, the Soviet Union presents an ultimatum to Romania requiring it to cede Bessarabia and the northern part of Bukovina.
*1941 &ndash; World War II: Soviet planes bomb Kassa, Hungary (now Koice, Slovakia), giving Hungary the impetus to declare war the next day.
*1942 &ndash; The first flight of the Grumman F6F Hellcat.
*1944 &ndash; World War II: The Battle of Osuchy in Osuchy, Poland, ends with the defeat of the Polish resistance forces.
*1945 &ndash; The United Nations Charter is signed in San Francisco.
*1948 &ndash; The Western allies begin an airlift to Berlin after the Soviet Union blockades West Berlin.
* 1948 &ndash; William Shockley files the original patent for the grown junction transistor, the first bipolar junction transistor.
* 1948 &ndash; Shirley Jackson's short story The Lottery is published in The New Yorker magazine.
*1952 &ndash; The Pan-Malayan Labour Party is founded in Malaya, as a union of statewise labour parties.
*1953 &ndash; Lavrentiy Beria,head of MVD, is arrested by Nikita Khrushchev and other members of the Politburo.
*1955 &ndash; The South African Congress Alliance adopts the Freedom Charter at the Congress of the People in Kliptown.
*1959 &ndash; The Saint Lawrence Seaway opens, opening North America's Great Lakes to ocean-going ships.
*1960 &ndash; The former British Protectorate of British Somaliland gains its independence as Somaliland. 
* 1960 &ndash; Madagascar gains its independence from France.
*1963 &ndash; U.S. President John F. Kennedy gave his "Ich bin ein Berliner" speech, underlining the support of the United States for democratic West Germany shortly after Soviet-supported East Germany erected the Berlin Wall.
*1973 &ndash; At Plesetsk Cosmodrome 9 people are killed in an explosion of a Cosmos 3-M rocket.
*1974 &ndash; The Universal Product Code is scanned for the first time to sell a package of Wrigley's chewing gum at the Marsh Supermarket in Troy, Ohio
* 1975 &ndash; Two FBI agents and a member of the American Indian Movement are killed in a shootout on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota; Leonard Peltier is later convicted of the murders in a controversial trial.
*1977 &ndash; The Yorkshire Ripper kills 16 year old shop assistant Jayne MacDonald in Leeds, changing public perception of the killer as she is the first victim who is not a prostitute.
*1978 &ndash; Air Canada Flight 189 to Toronto overruns the runway and crashes into the Etobicoke Creek ravine. Two of 107 passengers on board perish.
*1991 &ndash; Ten-Day War: the Yugoslav people's army begins the Ten-Day War in Slovenia.
*1995 &ndash; Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani deposes his father Khalifa bin Hamad al-Thani, the Emir of Qatar, in a bloodless coup.
*1997 &ndash; The U.S. Supreme Court rules that the Communications Decency Act violates the First Amendment to the United States Constitution.
*2000 &ndash; President Clinton announces the completion of the first survey of the entire human genome.
*2003 &ndash; The U.S. Supreme Court rules in Lawrence v. Texas that gender-based sodomy laws are unconstitutional.
*2006 &ndash; Mari Alkatiri, the first Prime Minister of East Timor, resigns after weeks of political unrest.
*2012 &ndash; The Waldo Canyon Fire descends into the Mountain Shadows neighborhood in Colorado Springs burning 347 homes in a matter of hours and killing two people.
*2013 &ndash; The U.S. Supreme Court rules that Section 3 of the Defense of Marriage Act is unconstitutional and in violation of the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution. 
* 2013 &ndash; Riots in China's Xinjiang region kill at least 36 people and injuring 21 others.

[[June 27]]

==Events==
*1358 &ndash; Republic of Dubrovnik is founded
*1497 &ndash; Cornish rebels Michael An Gof and Thomas Flamank are executed at Tyburn, London, England.
*1556 &ndash; The thirteen Stratford Martyrs are burned at the stake near London for their Protestant beliefs.
*1743 &ndash; War of the Austrian Succession: Battle of Dettingen: On the battlefield in Bavaria, George II personally leads troops into battle. The last time that a British monarch would command troops in the field.
*1759 &ndash; General James Wolfe begins the siege of Quebec.
*1760 &ndash; Cherokee warriors defeat British forces at the Battle of Echoee near present-day Otto, North Carolina during the Anglo-Cherokee War.
*1806 &ndash; British forces take Buenos Aires during the first British invasions of the Ro de la Plata.
*1844 &ndash; Joseph Smith, Jr., founder of the Latter Day Saint movement, and his brother Hyrum Smith, are murdered by a mob at the Carthage, Illinois jail.
*1895 &ndash; The inaugural run of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's Royal Blue from Washington, D.C., to New York, New York, the first U.S. passenger train to use electric locomotives.
*1898 &ndash; The first solo circumnavigation of the globe is completed by Joshua Slocum from Briar Island, Nova Scotia.
*1899 &ndash; A. E. J. Collins scores 628 runs not out, the highest-ever recorded score in cricket.
*1905 &ndash; Battleship Potemkin uprising: sailors start a mutiny aboard the battleship Potemkin, denouncing the crimes of autocracy, demanding liberty and an end to war.
*1927 &ndash; Prime Minister of Japan Tanaka Giichi leads a conference to discuss Japan's plans for China; later, a document detailing these plans, the "Tanaka Memorial" is leaked, although it is now considered a forgery.
*1941 &ndash; Romanian governmental forces, allies of Nazi Germany, launch one of the most violent pogroms in Jewish history in the city of Iai, (Romania), resulting in the murder of at least 13,266 Jews.
* 1941 &ndash; German troops capture the city of Biaystok during Operation Barbarossa.
*1946 &ndash; In the Canadian Citizenship Act, the Parliament of Canada establishes the definition of Canadian citizenship.
*1950 &ndash; The United States decides to send troops to fight in the Korean War.
*1952 &ndash; Guatemala passes Decree 900, ordering the redistribution of uncultivated land. 
*1954 &ndash; The world's first nuclear power station opens in Obninsk, near Moscow.
* 1954 &ndash; The 1954 FIFA World Cup quarterfinal match between Hungary and Brazil, highly anticipated to be exciting, instead turns violent, with three players ejected and further fighting continuing after the game.
*1957 &ndash; Hurricane Audrey makes landfall near the Texas-Louisiana border, killing over 400 people, mainly in and around Cameron, Louisiana.
*1971 &ndash; After only three years in business, rock promoter Bill Graham closes the Fillmore East in New York, New York, the "Church of Rock and Roll".
*1973 &ndash; The President of Uruguay Juan Mara Bordaberry dissolves Parliament and establishes a dictatorship.
*1974 &ndash; U.S. president Richard Nixon visits the Soviet Union.
*1976 &ndash; Air France Flight 139 (Tel Aviv-Athens-Paris) is hijacked en route to Paris by the PLO and redirected to Entebbe, Uganda.
*1977 &ndash; France grants independence to Djibouti.
*1980 &ndash; Italian Aerolinee Itavia Flight 870 mysteriously explodes in mid air while in route from Bologna to Palermo, killing all 81 on board. Also known in Italy as the Ustica disaster
*1981 &ndash; The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issues its "Resolution on Certain Questions in the History of Our Party Since the Founding of the People's Republic of China", laying the blame for the Cultural Revolution on Mao Zedong.
*1982 &ndash; Space Shuttle Columbia launched from the Kennedy Space Center on the final research and development flight mission, STS-4.
*1985 &ndash; U.S. Route 66 is officially removed from the United States Highway System.
*1988 &ndash; Gare de Lyon rail accident In Paris a train collides with a stationary train killing 56 people.
*1991 &ndash; Slovenia, after declaring independence two days before is invaded by Yugoslav troops, tanks, and aircraft starting the Ten-Day War.
*2007 &ndash; Tony Blair resigns as British Prime Minister, a position he had held since 1997.
* 2007 &ndash; The Brazilian Military Police invades the favelas of Complexo do Alemo in an episode which is remembered as the Complexo do Alemo massacre.
*2008 &ndash; In a highly scrutizined election President of Zimbabwe Robert Mugabe is re-elected in a landslide after his opponent Morgan Tsvangirai had withdrawn a week earlier, citing violence against his party's supporters.
*2013 &ndash; NASA launches the Interface Region Imaging Spectrograph, a space probe to observe the Sun.

* BBC: On This Day

* On This Day in Canada



[[June 28]]

In common years it is always in ISO week 26.

This date is the only date each year where both the month and day are different perfect numbers, June 6 being the only date where the month and day are the same perfect number.

==Events==
*1098 &ndash; Fighters of the First Crusade defeat Kerbogha of Mosull.
*1360 &ndash; Muhammed VI becomes the tenth Nasrid king of Granada after killing his brother-in-law Ismail II.
*1389 &ndash; Battle of Kosovo between Serbian and Turkish armies. 
*1461 &ndash; Edward IV is crowned King of England.
*1519 &ndash; Charles V is elected Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire.
*1635 &ndash; Guadeloupe becomes a French colony.
*1651 &ndash; The Battle of Beresteczko between Poland and Ukraine starts.
*1709 &ndash; Peter the Great defeats Charles XII of Sweden at the Battle of Poltava.
*1745 &ndash; War of the Austrian Succession: A New England colonial army captures Louisbourg, New France, after a forty-seven-day siege (New Style).
*1776 &ndash; The Battle of Sullivan's Island ends with the first decisive American victory in the American Revolutionary War leading to the commemoration of Carolina Day.
* 1776 &ndash; Thomas Hickey, Continental Army private and bodyguard to General George Washington, is hanged for mutiny and sedition.
*1778 &ndash; The American Continentals engage the British in the Battle of Monmouth Courthouse resulting in standstill and British withdrawal under cover of darkness.
*1807 &ndash; Second British invasion of the Ro de la Plata; John Whitelock lands at Ensenada on an attempt to recapture Buenos Aires and is defeated by the locals.
*1838 &ndash; Coronation of Victoria of the United Kingdom.
*1841 &ndash; The Paris Opera Ballet premieres Giselle in the Salle Le Peletier
*1859 &ndash; The first conformation dog show is held in Newcastle-upon-Tyne, England.
*1865 &ndash; The Army of the Potomac is disbanded.
*1880 &ndash; The Australian bushranger Ned Kelly is captured at Glenrowan.
*1881 &ndash; Secret treaty between Austria and Serbia.
*1882 &ndash; The Anglo-French Convention of 1882 marks the territorial boundaries between Guinea and Sierra Leone.
*1894 &ndash; Labor Day becomes an official US holiday.
*1895 &ndash; El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua form the Greater Republic of Central America.
* 1895 &ndash; Court of Private Land Claims rules James Reavis' claim to Barony of Arizona is "wholly fictitious and fraudulent."
*1896 &ndash; An explosion in the Newton Coal Company's Twin Shaft Mine in Pittston City, Pennsylvania results in a massive cave-in that kills 58 miners.
*1902 &ndash; The U.S. Congress passes the Spooner Act, authorizing President Theodore Roosevelt to acquire rights from Colombia for the Panama Canal.
*1904 &ndash; The runs aground and sinks
*1914 &ndash; Franz Ferdinand, Archduke of Austria and his wife Sophie are assassinated in Sarajevo by Bosnia Serb nationalist Gavrilo Princip, the casus belli of World War I.
*1919 &ndash; The Treaty of Versailles is signed in Paris, bringing fighting to an end in between Germany and the Allies of World War I.
*1921 &ndash; Serbian King Alexander I proclaimed the new constitution of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, known thereafter as the Vidovdan Constitution.
*1922 &ndash; The Irish Civil War begins with the shelling of the Four Courts in Dublin by Free State forces.
*1926 &ndash; Mercedes-Benz is formed by Gottlieb Daimler and Karl Benz merging their two companies.
*1936 &ndash; The Japanese puppet state of Mengjiang is formed in northern China.
*1940 &ndash; Romania cedes Bessarabia (current-day Moldova) to the Soviet Union.
*1942 &ndash; World War II: Nazi Germany started its strategic summer offensive against the Soviet Union, codenamed Case Blue
*1945 &ndash; Poland's Soviet-allied Provisional Government of National Unity is formed over a month after V-E Day.
*1948 &ndash; The Cominform circulates the "Resolution on the situation in the Communist Party of Yugoslavia"; Yugoslavia is expelled from the Communist bloc.
* 1948 &ndash; Boxer Dick Turpin beats Vince Hawkins at Villa Park in Birmingham to become the first black British boxing champion in the modern era.
*1950 &ndash; Korean War: Seoul is captured by North Korean troops.
* 1950 &ndash; Korean War: Suspected communist sympathizers, argued to be between 100,000 and 200,000 are executed in the Bodo League massacre.
* 1950 &ndash; Korean War: Packed with its own refugees fleeing Seoul and leaving their 5th Division stranded, South Korean forces blow up the Hangang Bridge to in attempt to slow North Korea's offensive.
* 1950 &ndash; Korean War: North Korean Army conducted Seoul National University Hospital Massacre.
*1956 &ndash; in Pozna, workers from HCP factory went to the streets, sparking one of the first major protests against communist government both in Poland and Europe.
*1964 &ndash; Malcolm X forms the Organization of Afro-American Unity.
*1967 &ndash; Israel annexes East Jerusalem.
*1969 &ndash; Stonewall Riots begin in New York City, marking the start of the Gay Rights Movement.
*1973 &ndash; Elections are held for the Northern Ireland Assembly, which will lead to power-sharing between unionists and nationalists in Northern Ireland for the first time.
*1976 &ndash; The Angolan court sentences US and UK mercenaries to death sentences and prison terms in the Luanda Trial.
*1978 &ndash; The United States Supreme Court, in Regents of the University of California v. Bakke bars quota systems in college admissions.
*1981 &ndash; A powerful bomb explodes in Tehran, killing 73 officials of Islamic Republic Party.
*1983 &ndash; Partial collapse of Connecticut's busy I-95 Mianus River Bridge, killing three.
*1987 &ndash; For the first time in military history, a civilian population is targeted for chemical attack when Iraqi warplanes bombed the Iranian town of Sardasht.
*1989 &ndash; On the 600th anniversary of the Battle of Kosovo, Slobodan Miloevi delivers the Gazimestan speech at the site of the historic battle.
*1992 &ndash; The Constitution of Estonia is signed into law.
*1994 &ndash; Members of the Aum Shinrikyo cult release sarin gas in Matsumoto, Japan; 7 persons are killed, 660 injured.
*1996 &ndash; The Constitution of Ukraine is signed into law.
*1997 &ndash; HolyfieldTyson II &ndash; Mike Tyson is disqualified in the 3rd round for biting a piece off Evander Holyfield's ear.
*2001 &ndash; Slobodan Miloevi is deported to ICTY to stand trial.
*2004 &ndash; Sovereign power is handed to the interim government of Iraq by the Coalition Provisional Authority, ending the U.S.-led rule of that nation.
*2009 &ndash; Honduran president Manuel Zelaya is ousted by a local military coup following a failed request to hold a referendum to rewrite the Honduran Constitution. This was the start of the 2009 Honduran political crisis.

[[July 20]]

==Events==
* 70 &ndash; Siege of Jerusalem &ndash; Titus, son of emperor Vespasian, storms the Fortress of Antonia north of the Temple Mount. The Roman army is drawn into street fights with the Zealots.
* 911 &ndash; Rollo lays siege to Chartres.
*1189 &ndash; Richard I of England officially invested as Duke of Normandy.
*1304 &ndash; Wars of Scottish Independence: Fall of Stirling Castle &ndash; King Edward I of England takes the stronghold using the War Wolf.
*1402 &ndash; Ottoman-Timurid Wars: Battle of Ankara &ndash; Timur, ruler of Timurid Empire, defeats forces of the Ottoman Empire sultan Bayezid I.
*1592 &ndash; During the first Japanese invasion of Korea, Japanese forces led by Toyotomi Hideyoshi captured Pyongyang, although they were ultimately unable to hold it.
*1738 &ndash; Canadian explorer Pierre Gaultier de Varennes et de La Vrendrye reaches the western shore of Lake Michigan.
*1799 &ndash; Tekle Giyorgis I begins his first of five reigns as Emperor of Ethiopia.
*1807 &ndash; Nicphore Nipce is awarded a patent by Napoleon for the Pyrolophore, the world's first internal combustion engine, after it successfully powered a boat upstream on the river Sane in France.
*1810 &ndash; Citizens of Bogot, New Granada declare independence from Spain.
*1864 &ndash; American Civil War: Battle of Peachtree Creek &ndash; Near Atlanta, Georgia, Confederate forces led by General John Bell Hood unsuccessfully attack Union troops under General William T. Sherman.
*1866 &ndash; Austro-Prussian War: Battle of Lissa &ndash; The Austrian Navy , led by Admiral Wilhelm von Tegetthoff, defeats the Italian Navy near the island of Vis in the Adriatic Sea.
*1871 &ndash; British Columbia joins the confederation of Canada.
*1885 &ndash; The Football Association legalizes professionalism in association football under pressure from the British Football Association.
*1903 &ndash; The Ford Motor Company ships its first car.
*1917 &ndash; World War I: The Corfu Declaration, which leads to the creation of the post-war Kingdom of Yugoslavia, is signed by the Yugoslav Committee and Kingdom of Serbia.
*1922 &ndash; The League of Nations awards mandates of Togoland to France and Tanganyika to the United Kingdom.
*1932 &ndash; In Washington, D.C., police fire tear gas on World War I veterans, part of the Bonus Expeditionary Force, who attempt to march to the White House.
*1934 &ndash; Labor unrest in the U.S.: as police in Minneapolis fire upon striking truck drivers, during the Minneapolis Teamsters Strike of 1934, killing two and wounding sixty-seven.
* 1934 &ndash; 1934 West Coast waterfront strike: In Seattle, Washington, police fire tear gas on and club 2,000 striking longshoremen. The governor of Oregon calls out the National Guard to break a strike on the Portland docks.
*1935 &ndash; Switzerland: A Royal Dutch Airlines plane en route from Milan to Frankfurt crashes into a Swiss mountain, killing thirteen.
*1936 &ndash; The Montreux Convention is signed in Switzerland, authorizing Turkey to fortify the Dardanelles and Bosphorus but guaranteeing free passage to ships of all nations in peacetime.
*1938 &ndash; The United States Department of Justice files suit in New York, New York against the motion picture industry charging violations of the Sherman Antitrust Act in regards to the studio system. The case would eventually result in a break-up of the industry in 1948.
*1940 &ndash; Denmark leaves the League of Nations.
* 1940 &ndash; California opens its first freeway, the Arroyo Seco Parkway.
*1941 &ndash; Soviet leader Joseph Stalin consolidates the Commissariats of Home Affairs and National Security to form the NKVD and names Lavrenti Beria its chief.
*1944 &ndash; World War II: Adolf Hitler survives an assassination attempt led by German Army Colonel Claus von Stauffenberg.
*1949 &ndash; Israel and Syria sign a truce to end their nineteen-month war.
*1950 &ndash; Cold War: In Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Harry Gold pleads guilty to spying for the Soviet Union by passing secrets from atomic scientist Klaus Fuchs.
*1951 &ndash; King Abdullah I of Jordan is assassinated by a Palestinian while attending Friday prayers in Jerusalem.
*1954 &ndash; Germany: Otto John, head of West Germany's secret service, defects to East Germany.
*1960 &ndash; Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) elects Sirimavo Bandaranaike Prime Minister, the world's first elected female head of government.
* 1960 &ndash; The Polaris missile is successfully launched from a submarine, the , for the first time.
*1961 &ndash; French military forces break the Tunisian siege of Bizerte.
*1964 &ndash; Vietnam War: Viet Cong forces attack the capital of Dinh Tuong Province, Cai Be, killing 11 South Vietnamese military personnel and 40 civilians (30 of which are children).
*1968 &ndash; The first International Special Olympics Summer Games are held at Soldier Field in Chicago, Ill, with about 1,000 athletes with intellectual disabilities.
*1969 &ndash; Apollo program: Apollo 11 successfully makes the first manned landing on the Moon in the Sea of Tranquility. Americans Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin become the first humans to walk on the Moon almost 7 hours later. (US Time)
* 1969 &ndash; A cease fire is announced between Honduras and El Salvador, 6 days after the beginning of the "Football War".
*1974 &ndash; Turkish occupation of Cyprus: Forces from Turkey invade Cyprus after a coup d'etat, organised by the dictator of Greece, against president Makarios.
*1976 &ndash; The American Viking 1 lander successfully lands on Mars.
*1977 &ndash; Johnstown, Pennsylvania is hit by a flash flood that kills eighty and causes $350 million in damage.
* 1977 &ndash; The Central Intelligence Agency releases documents under the Freedom of Information Act revealing it had engaged in mind control experiments.
*1982 &ndash; Hyde Park and Regents Park bombings: The Provisional IRA detonates two bombs in Hyde Park and Regents Park in central London, killing eight soldiers, wounding forty-seven people, and leading to the deaths of seven horses.
*1985 &ndash; The government of Aruba passes legislation to secede from the Netherlands Antilles.
*1989 &ndash; Burma's ruling junta puts opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi under house arrest.
*1992 &ndash; Vclav Havel resigns as president of Czechoslovakia.
*1997 &ndash; The fully restored (aka Old Ironsides) celebrates its 200th birthday by setting sail for the first time in 116 years.
*1999 &ndash; Falun Gong is banned in China, and a large scale crackdown of the practice is launched.
*2012 &ndash; A gunman (later revealed to be James Eagan Holmes), opens fire at a movie theater in Aurora, Colorado, killing 12 people and injuring 58 others.
*2013 &ndash; 17 government soldiers are killed in an attack by FARC revolutionaries in the Colombian department of Arauca.
