[[July 25]]

==Events==
* 285 &ndash; Diocletian appoints Maximian as Caesar, co-ruler.
* 306 &ndash; Constantine I is proclaimed Roman emperor by his troops.
* 315 &ndash; The Arch of Constantine is completed near the Colosseum in Rome to commemorate Constantine I's victory over Maxentius at the Milvian Bridge. 
* 864 &ndash; The Edict of Pistres of Charles the Bald orders defensive measures against the Viking.
*1139 &ndash; Battle of Ourique: The Almoravids, led by Ali ibn Yusuf, are defeated by Prince Afonso Henriques.
*1261 &ndash; The city of Constantinople is recaptured by Nicaean forces under the command of Alexios Strategopoulos, re-establishing the Byzantine Empire.
*1278 &ndash; The naval Battle of Algeciras takes place in the context of the Spanish Reconquista resulting in a victory for the Emirate of Granada and the Maranid Dynasty over the Kingdom of Castile.
*1456 &ndash; The Battle of Molinella: the first battle in Italy in which firearms are used extensively.
*1536 &ndash; Sebastin de Belalczar on his search of El Dorado founds the city of Santiago de Cali.
*1538 &ndash; The city of Guayaquil is founded by the Spanish Conquistador Francisco de Orellana and given the name Muy Noble y Muy Leal Ciudad de Santiago de Guayaquil.
*1547 &ndash; Henry II of France is crowned.
*1554 &ndash; Mary I marries Philip II of Spain at Winchester Cathedral.
*1567 &ndash; Don Diego de Losada founds the city of Santiago de Leon de Caracas, modern-day Caracas, the capital city of Venezuela. 
*1593 &ndash; Henry IV of France publicly converts from Protestantism to Roman Catholicism.
*1603 &ndash; James VI of Scotland is crowned king of England (James I of England), bringing the Kingdom of England and Kingdom of Scotland into personal union. Political union would occur in 1707.
*1609 &ndash; The English ship Sea Venture, en route to Virginia, is deliberately driven ashore during a storm at Bermuda to prevent its sinking; the survivors go on to found a new colony there.
*1693 &ndash; Ignacio de Maya founds the Real Santiago de las Sabinas, now known as Sabinas Hidalgo, Nuevo Len, Mexico.
*1722 &ndash; Dummer's War begins along the Maine-Massachusetts border.
*1755 &ndash; British governor Charles Lawrence and the Nova Scotia Council order the deportation of the Acadians. Thousands of Acadians are sent to the British Colonies in America, France and England. Some later move to Louisiana, while others resettle in New Brunswick.
*1759 &ndash; French and Indian War: in Western New York, British forces capture Fort Niagara from the French, who subsequently abandon Fort Rouill. 
*1783 &ndash; American Revolutionary War: The war's last action, the Siege of Cuddalore, is ended by a preliminary peace agreement.
*1788 &ndash; Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart completes his Symphony No. 40 in G minor (K550).
*1792 &ndash; The Brunswick Manifesto is issued to the population of Paris promising vengeance if the French Royal Family is harmed.
*1795 &ndash; The first stone of the Pontcysyllte Aqueduct is laid.
*1797 &ndash; Horatio Nelson loses more than 300 men and his right arm during the failed conquest attempt of Tenerife (Spain).
*1799 &ndash; At Abu Qir in Egypt, Napoleon I of France defeats 10,000 Ottomans under Mustafa Pasha. 
*1814 &ndash; War of 1812: Battle of Lundy's Lane &ndash; reinforcements arrive near Niagara Falls for General Riall's British and Canadian forces and a bloody, all-night battle with Jacob Brown's Americans commences at 18.00; the Americans retreat to Fort Erie.
*1824 &ndash; Costa Rica annexes Guanacaste from Nicaragua.
*1837 &ndash; The first commercial use of an electrical telegraph is successfully demonstrated by William Cooke and Charles Wheatstone on July 25, 1837 between Euston and Camden Town in London.
*1853 &ndash; Joaquin Murrieta, the famous Californio bandit known as "Robin Hood of El Dorado", is killed. 
*1861 &ndash; American Civil War: The United States Congress passes the Crittenden-Johnson Resolution, stating that the war is being fought to preserve the Union and not to end slavery.
*1866 &ndash; The United States Congress passes legislation authorizing the rank of General of the Army. Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant becomes the first to be promoted to this rank.
*1868 &ndash; Wyoming becomes a United States territory.
*1869 &ndash; The Japanese daimyo begin returning their land holdings to the emperor as part of the Meiji Restoration reforms. (Traditional Japanese Date: June 17, 1869).
*1893 &ndash; The Corinth Canal in the Gulf of Corinth, Greece is used for the first time.
*1894 &ndash; The First Sino-Japanese War begins when the Japanese fire upon a Chinese warship.
*1898 &ndash; After over two months of sea-based bombardment, the United States invasion of Puerto Rico begins with U.S. troops led by General Nelson Miles landing at harbor of Gunica, Puerto Rico.
*1908 &ndash; Ajinomoto is founded. Kikunae Ikeda of the Tokyo Imperial University discovers that a key ingredient in kombu soup stock is monosodium glutamate (MSG), and patents a process for manufacturing it. 
*1909 &ndash; Louis Blriot makes the first flight across the English Channel in a heavier-than-air machine from (Calais to Dover, England, United Kingdom) in 37 minutes.
*1915 &ndash; RFC Captain Lanoe Hawker becomes the first British military aviator to earn the Victoria Cross, for defeating three German two-seat observation aircraft in one day, over the Western Front.
*1917 &ndash; Sir Robert Borden introduces the first income tax in Canada as a "temporary" measure (lowest bracket is 4% and highest is 25%).
*1920 &ndash; Telecommunications: the first transatlantic two-way radio broadcast takes place.
* 1920 &ndash; France captures Damascus.
*1925 &ndash; Telegraph Agency of the Soviet Union (TASS) is established.
*1934 &ndash; The Nazis assassinate Austrian Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss in a failed coup attempt. 
*1940 &ndash; General Henri Guisan orders the Swiss Army to resist German invasion and makes surrender illegal.
*1942 &ndash; Norwegian Manifesto calls for nonviolent resistance to the Nazis.
*1943 &ndash; World War II: Benito Mussolini is forced out of office by his own Italian Grand Council and is replaced by Pietro Badoglio. 
*1944 &ndash; World War II: Operation Spring &ndash; one of the bloodiest days for the First Canadian Army during the war: 1,500 casualties, including 500 killed.
*1946 &ndash; Operation Crossroads: an atomic bomb is detonated underwater in the lagoon of Bikini Atoll.
* 1946 &ndash; At Club 500 in Atlantic City, New Jersey, Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis stage their first show as a comedy team.
*1952 &ndash; The U.S. non-incorporated territory of Puerto Rico adopts a constitution.
*1956 &ndash; 45 miles south of Nantucket Island, the Italian ocean liner collides with the MS Stockholm in heavy fog and sinks the next day, killing 51.
*1957 &ndash; The Republic of Tunisia is proclaimed.
*1958 &ndash; The African Regroupment Party (PRA) holds its first congress in Cotonou.
*1959 &ndash; SR.N1 hovercraft crosses the English Channel from Calais, France to Dover, England in just over 2 hours.
*1961 &ndash; In a speech John F. Kennedy emphasizes that any attack on Berlin is an attack on NATO.
*1965 &ndash; Bob Dylan goes electric as he plugs in at the Newport Folk Festival, signaling a major change in folk and rock music.
*1969 &ndash; Vietnam War: U.S. President Richard Nixon declares the Nixon Doctrine, stating that the United States now expects its Asian allies to take care of their own military defense. This is the start of the "Vietnamization" of the war.
*1973 &ndash; Soviet Mars 5 space probe is launched.
*1976 &ndash; Viking program: Viking 1 takes the famous Face on Mars photo.
*1978 &ndash; Puerto Rico police assassinate two nationalists in the Cerro Maravilla murders.
* 1978 &ndash; Louise Brown, the world's first "test tube baby" is born.
*1979 &ndash; Another section of the Sinai Peninsula is peacefully returned by Israel to Egypt.
*1983 &ndash; Black July: 37 Tamil political prisoners at the Welikada high security prison in Colombo are massacred by the fellow Sinhalese prisoners.
*1984 &ndash; Salyut 7 cosmonaut Svetlana Savitskaya becomes the first woman to perform a space walk.
*1993 &ndash; Israel launches a massive attack against Lebanon in what the Israelis call Operation Accountability, and the Lebanese call the Seven-Day War.
* 1993 &ndash; The Saint James Church massacre occurs in Kenilworth, Cape Town, South Africa.
*1994 &ndash; Israel and Jordan sign the Washington Declaration, that formally ends the state of war that had existed between the nations since 1948.
*1995 &ndash; A gas bottle explodes in Saint Michel station of line B of the RER (Paris regional train network). Eight are killed and 80 wounded.
*1996 &ndash; In a military coup in Burundi, Pierre Buyoya deposes Sylvestre Ntibantunganya.
*2000 &ndash; Air France Flight 4590, a Concorde supersonic passenger jet, F-BTSC, crashes just after takeoff from Paris killing all 109 aboard and 4 on the ground.
*2007 &ndash; Pratibha Patil is sworn in as India's first female president.
*2010 &ndash; WikiLeaks publishes classified documents about the War in Afghanistan, one of the largest leaks in U.S. military history.

[[June 10]]

==Events==
*671 &ndash; Emperor Tenji of Japan introduces a water clock (clepsydra) called Rokoku. The instrument, which measure time and indicates hours, is placed in the capital of tsu.
*1190 &ndash; Third Crusade: Frederick I Barbarossa drowns in the river Saleph while leading an army to Jerusalem.
*1329 &ndash; The Battle of Pelekanon results in a Byzantine defeat by the Ottoman Empire.
*1523 &ndash; Copenhagen is surrounded by the army of Frederick I of Denmark, as the city won't recognise him as the successor of Christian II of Denmark.
*1539 &ndash; Council of Trent: Paul III sends out letters to his bishops, delaying the Council due to war and the difficulty bishops had traveling to Venice.
*1619 &ndash; Thirty Years' War: Battle of Zblat, a turning point in the Bohemian Revolt.
*1624 &ndash; Signing of the Treaty of Compigne between France and the Netherlands.
*1692 &ndash; Salem witch trials: Bridget Bishop is hanged at Gallows Hill near Salem, Massachusetts, for "certaine Detestable Arts called Witchcraft & Sorceries".
*1719 &ndash; Jacobite Rising: Battle of Glen Shiel.
*1786 &ndash; A landslide dam on the Dadu River created by an earthquake ten days earlier collapses, killing 100,000 in the Sichuan province of China.
*1793 &ndash; The Jardin des Plantes museum opens in Paris. A year later, it becomes the first public zoo.
* 1793 &ndash; French Revolution: Following the arrests of Girondin leaders, the Jacobins gain control of the Committee of Public Safety installing the revolutionary dictatorship.
*1805 &ndash; First Barbary War: Yusuf Karamanli signs a treaty ending the hostilities between Tripolitania and the United States.
*1829 &ndash; The first Boat Race between the University of Oxford and the University of Cambridge takes place.
*1838 &ndash; Myall Creek massacre: Twenty-eight Aboriginal Australians are murdered.
*1854 &ndash; The first class of United States Naval Academy students graduate.
*1861 &ndash; American Civil War: Battle of Big Bethel - Confederate troops under John B. Magruder defeat a much larger Union force led by General Ebenezer W. Pierce in Virginia.
*1864 &ndash; American Civil War: Battle of Brice's Crossroads - Confederate troops under Nathan Bedford Forrest defeat a much larger Union force led by General Samuel D. Sturgis in Mississippi.
*1871 &ndash; Sinmiyangyo: Captain McLane Tilton leads 109 US Marines in a naval attack on Han River forts on Kanghwa Island, Korea.
*1878 &ndash; League of Prizren is established, to oppose the decisions of the Congress of Berlin and the Treaty of San Stephano, as a consequence of which the Albanian lands in Balkans were being partitioned and given to the neighbor states of Serbia, Montenegro, Bulgaria and Greece.
*1886 &ndash; Mount Tarawera in New Zealand erupts, killing 153 people and destroying the famous Pink and White Terraces.
*1898 &ndash; SpanishAmerican War: U.S. Marines land on the island of Cuba.
*1912 &ndash; The Villisca Axe Murders were discovered in Villisca, Iowa.
*1916 &ndash; An Arab Revolt against the Ottoman Empire led by Lawrence of Arabia breaks out.
*1918 &ndash; The Austro-Hungarian battleship sinks off the Croatian coast after being torpedoed by an Italian MAS motorboat; the event is recorded by camera from a nearby vessel.
*1924 &ndash; Fascists kidnap and kill Italian Socialist leader Giacomo Matteotti in Rome.
*1925 &ndash; Inaugural service for the United Church of Canada, a union of Presbyterian, Methodist, and Congregationalist churches, held in the Toronto Arena.
*1935 &ndash; Dr. Robert Smith takes his last drink, and Alcoholics Anonymous is founded in Akron, Ohio, United States, by him and Bill Wilson.
* 1935 &ndash; Chaco War ends: a truce is called between Bolivia and Paraguay who had been fighting since 1932.
*1936 &ndash; The Russian animation studio Soyuzmultfilm is founded.
*1940 &ndash; World War II: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt denounces Italy's actions with his "Stab in the Back" speech at the graduation ceremonies of the University of Virginia.
* 1940 &ndash; World War II: Norway surrenders to German forces.
* 1940 &ndash; World War II: Italy declares war on France and the United Kingdom.
*1942 &ndash; World War II: Nazis burn the Czech village of Lidice in reprisal for the killing of Reinhard Heydrich.
*1944 &ndash; World War II: Six hundred forty-two men, women and children are killed in the Oradour-sur-Glane Massacre in France.
* 1944 &ndash; World War II: In Distomo, Boeotia, Greece 218 men, women and children are massacred by German troops.
* 1944 &ndash; In baseball, 15-year old Joe Nuxhall of the Cincinnati Reds becomes the youngest player ever in a major-league game.
*1945 &ndash; Australian Imperial Forces land in Brunei Bay to liberate Brunei.
*1947 &ndash; Saab produces its first automobile.
*1957 &ndash; John Diefenbaker leads the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada to a stunning upset in the Canadian federal election, 1957, ending 22 years of Liberal Party government.
*1963 &ndash; Equal Pay Act of 1963 aimed at abolishing wage disparity based on sex (see Gender pay gap). It was signed into law on June 10, 1963 by John F. Kennedy as part of his New Frontier Program
*1967 &ndash; The Six-Day War ends: Israel and Syria agree to a cease-fire.
* 1967 &ndash; Argentina becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty.
*1977 &ndash; James Earl Ray escapes from Brushy Mountain State Prison in Petros, Tennessee, but is recaptured on June 13.
* 1977 &ndash; The Apple II, one of the first personal computers, goes on sale.
*1980 &ndash; The African National Congress in South Africa publishes a call to fight from their imprisoned leader Nelson Mandela.
*1990 &ndash; British Airways Flight 5390 lands safely at Southampton Airport after a blowout in the cockpit causes the captain to be partially sucked from the cockpit. There are no fatalities
* 1991  Eleven-year-old Jaycee Lee Dugard was kidnapped in South Lake Tahoe, California; she would remain a captive until 2009.
*1996 &ndash; Peace talks begin in Northern Ireland without the participation of Sinn Fin.
*1997 &ndash; Before fleeing his northern stronghold, Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot orders the killing of his defense chief Son Sen and 11 of Sen's family members.
*1999 &ndash; Kosovo War: NATO suspends its air strikes after Slobodan Miloevi agrees to withdraw Serbian forces from Kosovo.
*2001 &ndash; Pope John Paul II canonizes Lebanon's first female saint, Saint Rafqa.
*2002 &ndash; The first direct electronic communication experiment between the nervous systems of two humans is carried out by Kevin Warwick in the United Kingdom.
*2003 &ndash; The Spirit Rover is launched, beginning NASA's Mars Exploration Rover mission.

[[June 12]]

==Events==
*1381 &ndash; Peasants' Revolt: in England, rebels arrive at Blackheath.
*1418 &ndash; An insurrection delivers Paris to the Burgundians.
*1429 &ndash; Hundred Years' War: Joan of Arc leads the French army in their capture of the city and the English commander, William de la Pole, 1st Duke of Suffolk in the second day of the Battle of Jargeau.
*1550 &ndash; The city of Helsinki, Finland (belonging to Sweden at the time) is founded by King Gustav I of Sweden.
*1560 &ndash; Battle of Okehazama: Oda Nobunaga defeats Imagawa Yoshimoto.
*1653 &ndash; First Anglo-Dutch War: the Battle of the Gabbard begins and lasts until June 13.
*1665 &ndash; England installs a municipal government in New York City (the former Dutch settlement of New Amsterdam).
*1758 &ndash; French and Indian War: Siege of Louisbourg &ndash; James Wolfe's attack at Louisbourg, Nova Scotia commences.
*1775 &ndash; American Revolution: British general Thomas Gage declares martial law in Massachusetts. The British offer a pardon to all colonists who lay down their arms. There would be only two exceptions to the amnesty: Samuel Adams and John Hancock, if captured, were to be hanged.
*1776 &ndash; The Virginia Declaration of Rights is adopted.
*1798 &ndash; Irish Rebellion of 1798: Battle of Ballynahinch.
*1860 &ndash; The State Bank of the Russian Empire is established.
*1864 &ndash; American Civil War, Overland Campaign: Battle of Cold Harbor &ndash; Ulysses S. Grant gives the Confederate forces under Robert E. Lee a victory when he pulls his Union troops from their positions at Cold Harbor, Virginia and moves south.
*1889 &ndash; Eighty are killed in the Armagh rail disaster near Armagh in what is now Northern Ireland.
*1898 &ndash; Philippine Declaration of Independence: General Emilio Aguinaldo declares the Philippines' independence from Spain.
*1899 &ndash; New Richmond Tornado: the eighth deadliest tornado in U.S. history kills 117 people and injures around 200.
*1922 &ndash; At Windsor Castle, King George V receives the colours of the six Irish regiments that are to be disbanded &ndash; the Royal Irish Regiment, the Connaught Rangers, the South Irish Horse, the Prince of Wales's Leinster Regiment, the Royal Munster Fusiliers and the Royal Dublin Fusiliers.
*1939 &ndash; Shooting begins on Paramount Pictures' Dr. Cyclops, the first horror film photographed in three-strip Technicolor.
* 1939 &ndash; The Baseball Hall of Fame opens in Cooperstown, New York.
*1940 &ndash; World War II: Thirteen thousand British and French troops surrender to Major General Erwin Rommel at Saint-Valery-en-Caux.
*1942 &ndash; Anne Frank receives a diary for her thirteenth birthday.
*1943 &ndash; Holocaust: Germany liquidates the Jewish Ghetto in Brzeany, Poland (now Berezhany, Ukraine). Around 1,180 Jews are led to the city's old Jewish graveyard and shot.
*1944 &ndash; American paratroopers of the 101st Airborne Division secure the town of Carentan.
*1954 &ndash; Pope Pius XII canonises Dominic Savio, who was 14 years old at the time of his death, as a saint, making him the youngest unmartyred saint in the Roman Catholic Church.
*1963 &ndash; Civil rights leader Medgar Evers is murdered in front of his home in Jackson, Mississippi by Ku Klux Klan member Byron De La Beckwith.
*1964 &ndash; Anti-apartheid activist and ANC leader Nelson Mandela is sentenced to life in prison for sabotage in South Africa.
*1967 &ndash; The United States Supreme Court in Loving v. Virginia declares all U.S. state laws which prohibit interracial marriage to be unconstitutional.
* 1967 &ndash; Venera program: Venera 4 is launched (it will become the first space probe to enter another planet's atmosphere and successfully return data).
*1972 &ndash; The fast food restaurant chain Popeyes is founded in Arabi, Louisiana.
*1978 &ndash; David Berkowitz, the "Son of Sam" killer in New York City, is sentenced to 365 years in prison for six killings.
*1979 &ndash; Bryan Allen wins the second Kremer prize for a man powered flight across the English Channel in the Gossamer Albatross.
*1987 &ndash; The Central African Republic's former Emperor Jean-Bdel Bokassa is sentenced to death for crimes he had committed during his 13-year rule.
* 1987 &ndash; Cold War: At the Brandenburg Gate U.S. President Ronald Reagan publicly challenges Mikhail Gorbachev to tear down the Berlin Wall.
*1990 &ndash; Russia Day: The parliament of the Russian Federation formally declares its sovereignty.
*1991 &ndash; Russians elect Boris Yeltsin as the president of the republic.
* 1991 &ndash; 1991 Kokkadichcholai massacre: the Sri Lankan Army massacres 152 minority Tamil civilians in the village Kokkadichcholai near the eastern province town of Batticaloa, Sri Lanka.
*1993 &ndash; An election takes place in Nigeria which and is later annulled by the military Government led by Ibrahim Babangida.
*1994 &ndash; Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman are murdered outside her home in Los Angeles, California. O.J. Simpson is later acquitted of the killings, but is held liable in wrongful death civil suit.
* 1994 &ndash; The Boeing 777, the world's largest twinjet, makes its first flight.
*1996 &ndash; In Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, a panel of federal judges blocks a law against indecency on the internet.
*1997 &ndash; Queen Elizabeth II reopens the Globe Theatre in London.
*1999 &ndash; Kosovo War: Operation Joint Guardian begins when a NATO-led United Nations peacekeeping force (KFor) enters the province of Kosovo in Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
*2009 &ndash; A disputed presidential election in Iran leads to wide ranging protests in Iran and around the world.

[[John Horton Conway]]

John Horton Conway FRS (born 26 December 1937) is a British mathematician active in the theory of finite groups, knot theory, number theory, combinatorial game theory and coding theory. He has also contributed to many branches of recreational mathematics, notably the invention of the cellular automaton called the Game of Life. Conway is currently Professor of Mathematics and John Von Neumann Professor in Applied and Computational Mathematics at Princeton University. He is also currently a visiting professor at CUNY's Queens College. 

==Biography==
Conway's parents were Agnes Boyce and Cyril Horton Conway. He was born in Liverpool. He became interested in mathematics at a very early age and his mother recalled that he could recite the powers of two when he was four years old. At the age of eleven his ambition was to become a mathematician.

After leaving secondary school, Conway entered Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge Professor John Conway MA PhD FRS to study mathematics. He was awarded his Bachelor of Arts degree in 1959 and began to undertake research in number theory supervised by Harold Davenport. Having solved the open problem posed by Davenport on writing numbers as the sums of fifth powers, Conway began to become interested in infinite ordinals. It appears that his interest in games began during his years studying the Cambridge Mathematical Tripos, where he became an avid backgammon player, spending hours playing the game in the common room. He was awarded his doctorate in 1964 and was appointed as College Fellow and Lecturer in Mathematics at the University of Cambridge.

He left Cambridge in 1986 to take up the appointment to the John von Neumann Chair of Mathematics at Princeton University.

Conway resides in Princeton, New Jersey. He has seven children by various marriages, three grandchildren and four great-grand children. He has been married three times; his first wife was Eileen, and his second wife was Larissa. He has been married to his third wife, Diana, since 2001. 

==Research==

===Combinatorial game theory===
A single Gosper's Glider Gun creating "gliders" in Conway's Game of Life
Among amateur mathematicians, he is perhaps most widely known for his contributions to combinatorial game theory (CGT), a theory of partisan games. This he developed with Elwyn Berlekamp and Richard Guy, and with them also co-authored the book Winning Ways for your Mathematical Plays. He also wrote the book On Numbers and Games (ONAG) which lays out the mathematical foundations of CGT.

He is also one of the inventors of sprouts, as well as philosopher's football. He developed detailed analyses of many other games and puzzles, such as the Soma cube, peg solitaire, and Conway's soldiers. He came up with the angel problem, which was solved in 2006.

He invented a new system of numbers, the surreal numbers, which are closely related to certain games and have been the subject of a mathematical novel by Donald Knuth. He also invented a nomenclature for exceedingly large numbers, the Conway chained arrow notation. Much of this is discussed in the 0th part of ONAG.

He is also known for the invention of Conway's Game of Life, one of the early and still celebrated examples of a cellular automaton. His early experiments in that field were done with pen and paper, long before personal computers existed.

===Geometry===
In the mid-1960s with Michael Guy, son of Richard Guy, he established that there are sixty-four convex uniform polychora excluding two infinite sets of prismatic forms. They discovered the grand antiprism in the process, the only non-Wythoffian uniform polychoron. Conway has also suggested a system of notation dedicated to describing polyhedra called Conway polyhedron notation.

He extensively investigated lattices in higher dimensions, and determined the symmetry group of the Leech lattice.

===Geometric topology===
Conway's approach to computing the Alexander polynomial of knot theory involved skein relations, by a variant now called the Alexander-Conway polynomial. After lying dormant for more than a decade, this concept became central to work in the 1980s on the novel knot polynomials. Conway further developed tangle theory and invented a system of notation for tabulating knots, nowadays known as Conway notation, while completing the knot tables up to 10 crossings.

===Group theory===
He worked on the classification of finite simple groups and discovered the Conway groups. He was the primary author of the ATLAS of Finite Groups giving properties of many finite simple groups. He, along with collaborators, constructed the first concrete representations of some of the sporadic groups. More specifically, he discovered three sporadic groups based on the symmetry of the Leech lattice, which have been designated the Conway groups.

With Simon P. Norton he formulated the complex of conjectures relating the monster group with modular functions, which was named monstrous moonshine by them.

He introduced the Mathieu groupoid, an extension of the Mathieu group M12 to 13 points.

===Number theory===
As a graduate student, he proved the conjecture by Edward Waring that every integer could be written as the sum of 37 numbers, each raised to the fifth power, though Chen Jingrun solved the problem independently before the work could be published. Breakfast with John Horton Conway 

===Algebra===
He has also done work in algebra, particularly with quaternions. Together with Neil James Alexander Sloane, he invented the system of icosian. This Week's Finds in Mathematical Physics (Week 20) 

===Algorithmics===
For calculating the day of the week, he invented the Doomsday algorithm. The algorithm is simple enough for anyone with basic arithmetic ability to do the calculations mentally. Conway can usually give the correct answer in under two seconds. To improve his speed, he practices his calendrical calculations on his computer, which is programmed to quiz him with random dates every time he logs on. One of his early books was on finite state machines.

===Theoretical physics===
In 2004, Conway and Simon B. Kochen, another Princeton mathematician, proved the Free will theorem, a startling version of the No Hidden Variables principle of Quantum Mechanics. It states that given certain conditions, if an experimenter can freely decide what quantities to measure in a particular experiment, then elementary particles must be free to choose their spins in order to make the measurements consistent with physical law. In Conway's provocative wording: "if experimenters have free will, then so do elementary particles."

==Books==
He has (co-)written several books including the ATLAS of Finite Groups, Regular Algebra and Finite Machines, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups, The Sensual (Quadratic) Form, On Numbers and Games, Winning Ways for your Mathematical Plays, The Book of Numbers, On Quaternions and Octonions, The Triangle Book (written with Steve Sigur) http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/1391661.The_Triangle_Book and in summer 2008 published The Symmetries of Things with Chaim Goodman-Strauss and Heidi Burgiel.

==Awards and honours==
Conway received the Berwick Prize (1971), LMS Prizewinners was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society (1981), was the first recipient of the Plya Prize (LMS) (1987), won the Nemmers Prize in Mathematics (1998) and received the Leroy P. Steele Prize for Mathematical Exposition (2000) of the American Mathematical Society. He has an Erds number of one. 
Conway was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1981. His nomination reads:

[[July 10]]

==Events==
*48 BC &ndash; Battle of Dyrrhachium: Julius Caesar barely avoids a catastrophic defeat to Pompey in Macedonia.
* 138 &ndash; Emperor Hadrian dies after a heart failure at Baiae; he is buried at Rome in the Tomb of Hadrian beside his late wife, Vibia Sabina.
* 645 &ndash; Isshi Incident: Prince Naka-no-e and Fujiwara no Kamatari assassinate Soga no Iruka during a coup d'tat at the imperial palace.
* 988 &ndash; The Norse King Glun Iarainn recognises Mel Sechnaill II, High King of Ireland, and agrees to pay taxes and accept Brehon Law; the event is considered to be the founding of the city of Dublin.
*1212 &ndash; The most severe of several early fires of London burns most of the city to the ground.
*1460 &ndash; Richard Neville, 16th Earl of Warwick, defeats the king's Lancastrian forces and takes King Henry VI prisoner in the Battle of Northampton.
*1499 &ndash; The Portuguese explorer Nicolau Coelho returns to Lisbon, after discovering the sea route to India as a companion of Vasco da Gama.
*1519 &ndash; Zhu Chenhao declares the Ming Dynasty emperor Zhengde a usurper, beginning the Prince of Ning rebellion, and leads his army north in an attempt to capture Nanjing. 
*1553 &ndash; Lady Jane Grey takes the throne of England.
*1584 &ndash; William I of Orange is assassinated in his home in Delft, Holland, by Balthasar Grard.
*1645 &ndash; English Civil War: The Battle of Langport takes place.
*1778 &ndash; American Revolution: Louis XVI of France declares war on the Kingdom of Great Britain.
*1789 &ndash; Alexander Mackenzie reaches the Mackenzie River delta.
*1806 &ndash; The Vellore Mutiny is the first instance of a mutiny by Indian sepoys against the British East India Company.
*1821 &ndash; The United States takes possession of its newly bought territory of Florida from Spain.
*1832 &ndash; The U.S. President Andrew Jackson vetoes a bill that would re-charter the Second Bank of the United States.
*1850 &ndash; Millard Fillmore is inaugurated as the 13th President of the United States upon the death of President Zachary Taylor, 16 months into his term. 
*1877 &ndash; The then-villa of Mayagez, Puerto Rico, formally receives its city charter from the Royal Crown of Spain.
*1882 &ndash; War of the Pacific: Chile suffers its last military defeat in the Battle of La Concepcin when a garrison of 77 men is annihilated by a 1,300-strong Peruvian force, many of them armed with spears.
*1890 &ndash; Wyoming is admitted as the 44th U.S. state.
*1913 &ndash; Death Valley, California, hits 134 F (~56.7 C), the highest temperature recorded in the United States.
*1921 &ndash; Belfast's Bloody Sunday: 16 people are killed and 161 houses destroyed during rioting and gun battles in Belfast, Northern Ireland.
*1925 &ndash; Meher Baba begins his silence of 44 years. His followers observe Silence Day on this date in commemoration.
* 1925 &ndash; Scopes Trial: In Dayton, Tennessee, the so-called "Monkey Trial" begins with John T. Scopes, a young high school science teacher accused of teaching evolution in violation of the Butler Act.
*1938 &ndash; Howard Hughes sets a new record by completing a 91-hour airplane flight around the world.
*1940 &ndash; World War II: the Vichy government is established in France.
* 1940 &ndash; World War II: Battle of Britain &ndash; The German Luftwaffe begins attacking British convoys in the English Channel thus starting the battle (this start date is contested, though).
*1941 &ndash; Jedwabne Pogrom: the massacre of Jewish people living in and near the village of Jedwabne in Poland.
*1942 &ndash; Diplomatic relations between the Netherlands and the Soviet Union are established.
* 1942 &ndash; World War II: An American pilot spots a downed, intact Mitsubishi A6M Zero on Akutan Island (the "Akutan Zero") that the US Navy uses to learn the aircraft's flight characteristics.
*1946 &ndash; Hungarian hyperinflation sets a record with inflation of 348.46 percent per day, or prices doubling every eleven hours.
*1947 &ndash; Muhammad Ali Jinnah is recommended as the first Governor-General of Pakistan by the British Prime Minister, Clement Attlee.
*1951 &ndash; Korean War: Armistice negotiations begin at Kaesong.
*1962 &ndash; Telstar, the world's first communications satellite, is launched into orbit.
*1966 &ndash; The Chicago Freedom Movement, led by Martin Luther King, Jr., holds a rally at Soldier Field in Chicago, Illinois. As many as 60,000 people come to hear Dr. King as well as Mahalia Jackson, Stevie Wonder, and Peter Paul and Mary. 
*1967 &ndash; Uruguay becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty.
*1967 &ndash; New Zealand adopts decimal currency
*1971 &ndash; Hassan II of Morocco survives an attempted coup d'tat, which lasts until June 11.
*1973 &ndash; The Bahamas gain full independence within the Commonwealth of Nations.
* 1973 &ndash; National Assembly of Pakistan passes a resolution on the recognition of Bangladesh.
* 1973 &ndash; John Paul Getty III, a grandson of the oil magnate J. Paul Getty, is kidnapped in Rome, Italy.
*1976 &ndash; The Seveso disaster occurs in Italy.
* 1976 &ndash; One American and three British mercenaries are executed in Angola following the Luanda Trial.
*1977 &ndash; Alexandr Zagirnyak and Gennadi Sheludko hijack a Tupolev Tu-134 en route from Petrozavodsk to Leningrad and try to force the pilot to fly to Sweden. The plane lands in Helsinki instead. The hijackers surrender the next day and are returned to the Soviet Union.
*1978 &ndash; World News Tonight premieres on ABC.
* 1978 &ndash; President Moktar Ould Daddah of Mauritania is ousted in a bloodless coup d'tat.
*1980 &ndash; Alexandra Palace burns down for a second time.
*1985 &ndash; The Greenpeace vessel Rainbow Warrior is bombed and sunk in Auckland harbour by French DGSE agents, killing Fernando Pereira.
*1991 &ndash; The South African cricket team is readmitted into the International Cricket Council following the end of Apartheid.
* 1991 &ndash; Boris Yeltsin takes office as the first elected President of Russia.
*1992 &ndash; In Miami, Florida, the former Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega is sentenced to 40 years in prison for drug and racketeering violations.
*1997 &ndash; In London scientists report the findings of the DNA analysis of a Neanderthal skeleton which supports the "out of Africa theory" of human evolution placing an "African Eve" at 100,000 to 200,000 years ago.
* 1997 &ndash; Miguel ngel Blanco, a member of Partido Popular (Spain), is kidnapped in the Basque city of Ermua by ETA members, sparking widespread protests.
*1998 &ndash; Roman Catholic sex abuse cases: The Diocese of Dallas agrees to pay $23.4 million to nine former altar boys who claimed they were sexually abused by Rudolph Kos, a former priest.
*2000 &ndash; A leaking southern Nigerian petroleum pipeline explodes, killing about 250 villagers scavenging gasoline.
* 2000 &ndash; EADS, the world's second-largest aerospace group is formed by the merger of Arospatiale-Matra, DASA, and CASA.
*2002 &ndash; At a Sotheby's auction, Peter Paul Rubens' painting The Massacre of the Innocents is sold for 49.5million (US$76.2 million) to Lord Thomson.
*2003 &ndash; A Neoplan bus, owned by Kowloon Motor Bus, collides with a truck, falls off a bridge on Tuen Mun Road, Hong Kong, and plunges into the underlying valley, killing 21 people. This is the deadliest traffic accident to date in Hong Kong.
*2005 &ndash; Hurricane Dennis slams into the Florida Panhandle, causing billions of dollars in damage.
*2007 &ndash; Erden Eru begins the first solo human-powered circumnavigation of the world.
*2008 &ndash; Former Macedonian Interior Minister Ljube Bokoski is acquitted of all charges by a United Nations Tribunal accusing him of war crimes.
*2011 &ndash; Russian cruise ship Bulgaria sunk in Volga near Syukeyevo, Tatarstan, leading to 122 deaths.

[[June 24]]

==Events==
* 109 &ndash; Roman emperor Trajan inaugurates the Aqua Traiana, an aqueduct that channels water from Lake Bracciano, 40 km north-west of Rome.
* 474 &ndash; Julius Nepos forces Roman usurper Glycerius to abdicate the throne and proclaims himself Emperor of the Western Roman Empire.
* 637 &ndash; The Battle of Moira is fought between the High King of Ireland and the Kings of Ulster and Dalriada. It is claimed to be largest battle in the history of Ireland.
* 972 &ndash; Battle of Cedynia, the first documented victory of Polish forces, takes place.
*1128 &ndash; Battle of So Mamede, near Guimares: forces led by Alfonso I defeat forces led by his mother Teresa of Len and her lover Fernando Prez de Traba. After this battle, the future king calls himself "Prince of Portugal", the first step towards "official independence" that will be reached in 1139 after the Battle of Ourique.
*1230 &ndash; The Siege of Jan started in the context of the Spanish Reconquista.
*1314 &ndash; First War of Scottish Independence: the Battle of Bannockburn concludes with a decisive victory by Scottish forces led by Robert the Bruce, though England did not recognize Scottish independence until 1328 with the signing of the Treaty of Edinburgh-Northampton.
*1340 &ndash; Hundred Years' War: Battle of Sluys &ndash; The French fleet is almost completely destroyed by the English Fleet commanded in person by King Edward III.
*1374 &ndash; A sudden outbreak of St. John's Dance causes people in the streets of Aachen, Germany, to experience hallucinations and begin to jump and twitch uncontrollably until they collapse from exhaustion.
*1497 &ndash; John Cabot lands in North America at Newfoundland leading the first European exploration of the region since the Vikings.
*1509 &ndash; Henry VIII and Catherine of Aragon are crowned King and Queen of England.
*1535 &ndash; The Anabaptist state of Mnster is conquered and disbanded.
*1571 &ndash; Miguel Lopez de Legazpi founds Manila, the capital of the Republic of the Philippines.
*1597 &ndash; The first Dutch voyage to the East Indies reaches Bantam (on Java).
*1604 &ndash; Samuel de Champlain discovers the mouth of the Saint John River, site of Reversing Falls and the present day city of Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada.
*1622 &ndash; Battle of Macau: The Dutch attempt but fail to capture Macau.
*1717 &ndash; The Premier Grand Lodge of England, the first Masonic Grand Lodge in the world (now the United Grand Lodge of England), is founded in London, England.
*1779 &ndash; American Revolutionary War: The Great Siege of Gibraltar begins.
*1793 &ndash; The first Republican constitution in France is adopted.
*1812 &ndash; Napoleonic Wars: Napoleon's Grande Arme crosses the Neman River beginning the invasion of Russia.
*1813 &ndash; Battle of Beaver Dams: a British and Indian combined force defeats the United States Army.
*1821 &ndash; The Battle of Carabobo takes place. It is the decisive battle in the war of independence of Venezuela from Spain.
*1846 &ndash; The saxophone is patented by Adolphe Sax in Paris, France.
*1859 &ndash; Battle of Solferino (Battle of the Three Sovereigns): Sardinia and France defeat Austria in Solferino, northern Italy.
*1866 &ndash; Battle of Custoza: an Austrian army defeats the Italian army during the Austro-Prussian War.
*1880 &ndash; First performance of O Canada, the song that would become the national anthem of Canada, at the Congrs national des Canadiens-Franais.
*1894 &ndash; Marie Francois Sadi Carnot is assassinated by Sante Geronimo Caserio.
*1902 &ndash; King Edward VII of the United Kingdom develops appendicitis, delaying his coronation.
*1913 &ndash; Greece and Serbia annul their alliance with Bulgaria.
*1916 &ndash; Mary Pickford becomes the first female film star to sign a million dollar contract.
* 1916 &ndash; World War I: the Battle of the Somme begins with a week-long artillery bombardment on the German Line.
*1918 &ndash; First airmail service in Canada from Montreal to Toronto.
*1932 &ndash; A bloodless Revolution instigated by the People's Party ends the absolute power of King Prajadhipok of Siam (now Thailand).
*1938 &ndash; Pieces of a meteor, estimated to have weighed 450 metric tons when it hit the Earth's atmosphere and exploded, land near Chicora, Pennsylvania.
*1939 &ndash; Siam is renamed Thailand by Plaek Pibulsonggram, the country's third prime minister.
*1947 &ndash; Kenneth Arnold makes the first widely reported UFO sighting near Mount Rainier, Washington.
*1948 &ndash; Start of the Berlin Blockade: the Soviet Union makes overland travel between West Germany and West Berlin impossible.
*1949 &ndash; The first television western, Hopalong Cassidy, is aired on NBC starring William Boyd.
*1954 &ndash; First Indochina War: Battle of Mang Yang Pass  Vietminh troops belonging to the 803rd Regiment ambush G.M. 100 of France in An Kh.
*1957 &ndash; In Roth v. United States, the U.S. Supreme Court rules that obscenity is not protected by the First Amendment.
*1963 &ndash; The United Kingdom grants Zanzibar internal self-government.
*1967 &ndash; The worst caving disaster in British history takes six lives at Mossdale Caverns.
*1981 &ndash; The Humber Bridge is opens to traffic, connecting Yorkshire and Lincolnshire. It would be the world's longest single-span suspension bridge for 17 years.
*1982 &ndash; "The Jakarta Incident": British Airways Flight 9 flies into a cloud of volcanic ash thrown up by the eruption of Mount Galunggung, resulting in the failure of all four engines.
*1989 &ndash; Jiang Zemin succeeds Zhao Ziyang to become the General Secretary of the Communist Party of China after 1989 Tiananmen Square Protests.
*1995 &ndash; "Rugby World Cup final": South Africa defeats New Zealand, Nelson Mandela presents Francois Pienaar with the Webb-Ellis trophy in an iconic post-apartheid moment.
*2002 &ndash; The Igandu train disaster in Tanzania kills 281, the worst train accident in African history.
*2004 &ndash; In New York, capital punishment is declared unconstitutional.
*2010 &ndash; Kevin Rudd is deposed as Prime Minister of Australia and leader of the Australian Labor Party. Julia Gillard wins the subsequent leadership ballot.
*2010 &ndash; John Isner of the United States defeats Nicolas Mahut of France at Wimbledon, in the longest match in professional tennis history.
*2012 &ndash; The last known individual of Chelonoidis nigra abingdonii, a subspecies of the Galpagos tortoise, dies.

* Battle of Carabobo Day (Venezuela)
* Christian Feast Day:
** Nativity of St. John the Baptist
** June 24 (Eastern Orthodox liturgics)

* Day of the Caboclo (Amazonas State, Brazil)
* Discovery Day, observed on the nearest Monday (Newfoundland and Labrador)
* Earliest day on which Mother's Day can fall, while June 30 is the latest; celebrated on the last Sunday in June. (Kenya)
* Feast of Ramat (Bah' Faith)
* Inti Raymi, a winter solstice festival and a New Year in the Andes of the Southern Hemisphere (Sacsayhuamn)
* St John's Day and the second day of the Midsummer celebrations (although this is not the astronomical summer solstice, see June 20) (Roman Catholic Church, Northern Europe), and its related observances: 
** Jaanipev (Estonia)
** Ji (Latvia)
** Jnsmessa (Iceland)
** Midsummer Day (England)
** National Holiday (Quebec) 
** Saint Jonas' Festival or Jonins (Lithuania)
** Snziene (western Carpathian Mountains of Romania)

[[January 30]]

==Events==
*1018 &ndash; The Peace of Bautzen is signed between Poland and Germany.
*1607 &ndash; An estimated 200 square miles (51,800 ha) along the coasts of the Bristol Channel and Severn Estuary in the Kingdom of England are destroyed by massive flooding, resulting in an estimated 2,000 deaths.
*1648 &ndash; Eighty Years' War: The Treaty of Mnster and Osnabrck is signed, ending the conflict between the Netherlands and Spain.
*1649 &ndash; King Charles I of England is beheaded.
*1661 &ndash; Oliver Cromwell, Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England is ritually executed two years after his death, on the anniversary of the execution of the monarch he himself deposed.
*1667 &ndash; The PolishLithuanian Commonwealth cedes Kiev, Smolensk, and left-bank Ukraine to the Tsardom of Russia in the Treaty of Andrusovo.
*1703 &ndash; The Forty-seven Ronin, under the command of ishi Kuranosuke, avenge the death of their master.
*1790 &ndash; The first boat specializing as a lifeboat is tested on the River Tyne.
*1806 &ndash; The original Lower Trenton Bridge (also called the Trenton Makes the World Takes Bridge), which spans the Delaware River between Morrisville, Pennsylvania and Trenton, New Jersey, is opened.
*1820 &ndash; Edward Bransfield sights the Trinity Peninsula and claims the discovery of Antarctica.
*1826 &ndash; The Menai Suspension Bridge, considered the world's first modern suspension bridge, connecting the Isle of Anglesey to the north West coast of Wales, is opened.
*1835 &ndash; In the first assassination attempt against a President of the United States, Richard Lawrence attempts to shoot president Andrew Jackson, but fails and is subdued by a crowd, including several congressmen.
*1841 &ndash; A fire destroys two-thirds of Mayagez, Puerto Rico.
*1847 &ndash; Yerba Buena, California is renamed San Francisco.
*1858 &ndash; The first Hall concert is given in Manchester, England, marking the official founding of The Hall orchestra as a full-time, professional orchestra.
*1862 &ndash; The first American ironclad warship, the is launched.
*1889 &ndash; Archduke Crown Prince Rudolf of Austria, heir to the Austro-Hungarian crown, is found dead with his mistress Baroness Mary Vetsera in the Mayerling.
*1902 &ndash; The first Anglo-Japanese Alliance is signed in London.
*1908 &ndash; Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi is released from prison by Jan C. Smuts after being tried and sentenced to 2 months in jail earlier in the month.
*1911 &ndash; The destroyer makes the first airplane rescue at sea saving the life of James McCurdy 10 miles from Havana, Cuba.
* 1911 &ndash; The Canadian Naval Service becomes the Royal Canadian Navy.
*1913 &ndash; The British House of Lords rejects the Irish Home Rule Bill.
*1925 &ndash; The Government of Turkey throws Patriarch Constantine VI out of Istanbul.
*1933 &ndash; Adolf Hitler is sworn in as Chancellor of Germany.
*1942 &ndash; World War II: Japanese forces invade the island of Ambon in the Dutch East Indies.
*1943 &ndash; World War II: Second day of the Battle of Rennell Island. The is sunk and a U.S. destroyer is heavily damaged by Japanese torpedoes.
*1944 &ndash; World War II: The Battle of Cisterna, part of Operation Shingle, begins in central Italy.
* 1944 &ndash; World War II: American troops land on Majuro.
*1945 &ndash; World War II: The Wilhelm Gustloff, overfilled with German refugees, sinks in the Baltic Sea after being torpedoed by a Soviet submarine, leading to the deadliest known maritime disaster, killing approximately 9,500 people.
* 1945 &ndash; World War II: Raid at Cabanatuan: 126 American Rangers and Filipino resistance fighters liberate over 500 prisoners from the Cabanatuan POW camp.
*1948 &ndash; Indian pacifist and leader Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, known for his non-violent freedom struggle, is assassinated by Nathuram Godse, a Hindu extremist.
*1956 &ndash; American civil rights leader Martin Luther King, Jr.'s home is bombed in retaliation for the Montgomery Bus Boycott.
*1959 &ndash; , said to be the safest ship afloat and "unsinkable" like the , strikes an iceberg on her maiden voyage and sinks, killing all 95 aboard.
*1960 &ndash; The African National Party is founded in Chad, through the merger of traditionalist parties.
*1964 &ndash; Ranger program: Ranger 6 is launched.
* 1964 &ndash; In a bloodless coup, General Nguyn Khnh overthrows General Dng Vn Minh's military junta in South Vietnam.
*1965 &ndash; Winston Churchill's funeral.
*1968 &ndash; Vietnam War: Tet Offensive launch by forces of the Viet Cong and North Vietnamese Army against South Vietnam, the United States, and their allies.
*1969 &ndash; The Beatles' last public performance, on the roof of Apple Records in London. The impromptu concert is broken up by the police.
*1971 &ndash; Carole King's Tapestry album is released to become the longest charting album by a female solo artist and sell 24 million copies worldwide. 
*1972 &ndash; Bloody Sunday: British Paratroopers open fire on and kill fourteen unarmed civil rights/anti-internment marchers in Derry, Northern Ireland.
* 1972 &ndash; Pakistan withdraws from the Commonwealth of Nations.
*1975 &ndash; The Monitor National Marine Sanctuary is established as the first United States National Marine Sanctuary.
*1979 &ndash; A Varig 707-323C freighter, flown by the same commander as Flight 820, disappears over the Pacific Ocean 30 minutes after taking off from Tokyo.
*1982 &ndash; Richard Skrenta writes the first PC virus code, which is 400 lines long and disguised as an Apple boot program called "Elk Cloner".
*1989 &ndash; The American embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan closes.
*1994 &ndash; Pter Lk becomes the youngest chess grandmaster.
*1995 &ndash; Workers from the National Institutes of Health announce the success of clinical trials testing the first preventive treatment for sickle-cell disease.
*2000 &ndash; Off the coast of Ivory Coast, Kenya Airways Flight 431 crashes into the Atlantic Ocean, killing 169.

[[January 29]]

==Events==
* 757 &ndash; An Lushan, leader of a revolt against the Tang Dynasty and emperor of Yan, is murdered by his own son, An Qingxu.
* 904 &ndash; Sergius III comes out of retirement to take over the papacy from the deposed antipope Christopher.
*1676 &ndash; Feodor III becomes Tsar of Russia.
*1814 &ndash; France defeats Russia and Prussia in the Battle of Brienne.
*1819 &ndash; Stamford Raffles lands on the island of Singapore.
*1834 &ndash; US President Andrew Jackson orders first use of federal soldiers to suppress a labor dispute.
*1845 &ndash; "The Raven" is published in the New York Evening Mirror, the first publication with the name of the author, Edgar Allan Poe
*1850 &ndash; Henry Clay introduces the Compromise of 1850 to the U.S. Congress.
*1856 &ndash; Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom issues a Warrant under the Royal sign-manual that establishes the Victoria Cross to recognise acts of valour by British military personnel during the Crimean War. 
*1861 &ndash; Kansas is admitted as the 34th U.S. state.
*1863 &ndash; Bear River Massacre.
*1886 &ndash; Karl Benz patents the first successful gasoline-driven automobile.
*1891 &ndash; Liliuokalani is proclaimed the last monarch and only queen regnant of the Kingdom of Hawaii. 
*1900 &ndash; The American League is organized in Philadelphia with eight founding teams.
*1907 &ndash; Charles Curtis of Kansas becomes the first Native American U.S. Senator.
*1916 &ndash; World War I: Paris is first bombed by German zeppelins.
*1918 &ndash; UkrainianSoviet War: The Bolshevik Red Army, on its way to besiege Kiev, is met by a small group of military students at the Battle of Kruty.
* 1918 &ndash; UkrainianSoviet War: An armed uprising organized by the Bolsheviks in anticipation of the encroaching Red Army begins at the Kiev Arsenal, which will be put down six days later.
*1936 &ndash; The first inductees into the Baseball Hall of Fame are announced.
*1940 &ndash; Three trains on the Sakurajima Line, in Osaka, Japan, collide and explode while approaching Ajikawaguchi Station. 181 people are killed.
*1941 &ndash; Alexandros Koryzis becomes Prime Minister of Greece upon the sudden death of his predecessor, dictator Ioannis Metaxas.
*1943 &ndash; The first day of the Battle of Rennell Island, U.S. cruiser Chicago is torpedoed and heavily damaged by Japanese bombers.
*1944 &ndash; World War II: Approximately 38 people are killed and about a dozen injured when the Polish village of Koniuchy (present-day Kanikai, Lithuania) is attacked by Soviet partisan units. 
* 1944 &ndash; In Bologna, Italy, the Anatomical theatre of the Archiginnasio is destroyed in an air-raid.
*1963 &ndash; The first inductees into the Pro Football Hall of Fame are announced.
*1967 &ndash; The "ultimate high" of the hippie era, the Mantra-Rock Dance, takes place in San Francisco and features Janis Joplin, Grateful Dead, and Allen Ginsberg.
*1989 &ndash; Hungary establishes diplomatic relations with South Korea, making it the first Eastern Bloc nation to do so
*1991 &ndash; Gulf War: The Battle of Khafji, the first major ground engagement of the war, as well as its deadliest, begins.
*1996 &ndash; President Jacques Chirac announces a "definitive end" to French nuclear weapons testing.
* 1996 &ndash; La Fenice, Venice's opera house, is destroyed by fire.
*1998 &ndash; In Birmingham, Alabama, a bomb explodes at an abortion clinic, killing one and severely wounding another. Serial bomber Eric Robert Rudolph is suspected as the culprit.
*2001 &ndash; Thousands of student protesters in Indonesia storm parliament and demand that President Abdurrahman Wahid resign due to alleged involvement in corruption scandals.
*2002 &ndash; In his State of the Union address, President George W. Bush describes "regimes that sponsor terror" as an Axis of evil, in which he includes Iraq, Iran and North Korea.
*2005 &ndash; The first direct commercial flights from mainland China (from Guangzhou) to Taiwan since 1949 arrived in Taipei. Shortly afterwards, a China Airlines flight lands in Beijing.
*2006 &ndash; India's Irfan Pathan became the first bowler to take a Test cricket hat-trick in the opening over of a match. 
*2009 &ndash; The Supreme Constitutional Court of Egypt rules that people who do not adhere to one of the three government-recognised religions, while not allowed to list any belief outside of those three, are still eligible to receive government identity documents.
* 2009 &ndash; Governor of Illinois Rod Blagojevich is removed from office following his conviction of several corruption charges, including the alleged solicitation of personal benefit in exchange for an appointment to the United States Senate as a replacement for then-U.S. president-elect Barack Obama.
*2013 &ndash; SCAT Airlines Flight 760 crashes near the Kazakh city of Almaty, killing 21 people.
